item.title: WAY-2C -machine vision for real-time color-based recognition and control.
item.author: Robert McConnell
item.description:
Posted by: Robert McConnell to Vendor/Suppliers:WAY-2C -machine vision for real-time color-based recognition and control.

WAY-2C can now be controlled in real time over a network. This new feature makes it easy to instantly pass WAY-2C new training and/or classification instructions and locations in response to data from external sources and then obtain a timely response as to what the camera sees. Using commands from the network the suite of enabled reference classes can be kept updated in response to changing surroundings and conditions.

item.title: Sick LD LRS Question ...
item.author: Jason
item.description:
Posted by: Jason to Technology:Sick LD LRS Question ...

Hi everyone,



I was hoping maybe someone out there is familiar with the Sick LD LRS
1000. I am currently working with the unit, and I am writing a driver
for it. Although I can successfully setup a TCP connection with it and
send it a command, it fails to respond. I've verified with Wireshark
that my code is behaving correctly. Messages are being properly
constructed and pushed into the network; however (despite receiving the
message), the Sick simply does not respond. The message I am sending
is shown in the telegram protocol manual for the Sick LD-OEM/LD-LRS.
Since the manual is riddled with errors (for instance, they give the
wrong port number, mislabel packets, and never specify the default IP
of the Sick LD LRS), I believe the issue lies with their protocol
specification in that document. Has anyone else had a similar issue
or experienced this?? Were you able to find an accurate specification
for the Ethernet protocol for the Sick LD LRS. Additionally, I should
note that I have had previous experience implementing drivers for Sick
lidars, and have also had issues with their telegram protocol
specification before; however, in those cases, I was able to identify
and resolve the manual's errors.



Has anyone else experienced this? Can anyone confirm the validity of the telegram
protocol in that manual?



Thanks so much,

Jason

item.title: Preliminary rules = CDL
item.author: pgrayson@aimagic.org
item.description:
Posted by: pgrayson@aimagic.org to Rules:Preliminary rules = CDL

Sparky,

You are familar with the Track "A" and Track "B", but there is also another group. Since we are lettering things, I am calling it Track "C". This third group are teams that are not on the DARPA list but are still working on solving the Army's problem, which is actually the point of it all - race or not. We are continuing to use the Urban Challenge rules so that our vehicle will be ready for the next race if no one wins this one.

Over the years we have had many vehicles of many types. The vehicle we are building up now is an M-215, AGV WENDY DARLING, is Lots of work left to do on it. Check out our website and our Yahoo news group linked from our home page. I will try to get some fresh pictures up in the next couple of days.

I worked on the driverless vehicle project that was before the Grand Challenge. It was at the end of the first Gulf War 1990/1991 and the question was how to get on driver to drive a half dozen ammo trucks at one time. Later that turned into the DARPA Grand Challenge.

GO ROBOTS !
Paul F. Grayson - Chief Engineer
AMERICAN INDUSTRIAL MAGIC, LLC
Racing to build technology that saves soldier's lives.

Posted by: pgrayson@aimagic.org to Rules:Preliminary rules = CDL

Hi everyone,

Lots of things have changed.

We are currently a Track "C" team - that is a team working independently on solving the driverless problem, no prize money, no grant money, just a lot of lives that can be saved and a cool engineering / educational opportunity.

Considering the rules of the race, it looks our automatic guided vehicle AGV WENDY DARLING is the best choice out of our three vehicles to focus on. It is a classic M-215 Army truck with the shorter of the two options wheel base. Light weight by today's truck standards it gets pretty good gas milage.

If you are looking for a team to join so that you can keep working on solving the problem, please consider joining my team. We are getting ready for the next race.

item.title: lane_width value for 4.5m?
item.author: Jeffferson Joe
item.description:
Posted by: Jeffferson Joe to Miscellaneous:lane_width value for 4.5m?

The RNDF specifications say that the value for lane_width should be an integer.
The 4.5m width specification equates to about 14.76 feet.

So should we use 14, 15, or 14.76 as a value for lane_width?

item.title: ITFR00
item.author: DaveB
item.description:
Posted by: DaveB to Rules:ITFR00


As Phil Stevenson says, at: http://gis.ou.edu/pipermail/okgis/2004-Oc tober/000266.html

"Every time I use the term WGS84 I really mean ITRF00 because there is not a way for me to determine an actual WGS84 position."

Many high-accuracy GPS systems use the OmniSTAR corrections. Their site at http://www.omnistar.com/faq.html says:

"A. OmniSTAR VBS in North America is on the NAD83 datum and ITRF00 in all other OmniSTAR world areas. OmniSTAR HP and XP are in ITRF00, worldwide."

Since VBS is their least accurate system, you can assume the position reported by your GPS is in ITRF00.

item.title: ITFR00
item.author: Tyler Folsom
item.description:
Posted by: Tyler Folsom to Rules:ITFR00

It wasn't the ITRF00 that confused me so much as DARPA's replacing "float" with the undefined "fixed". To me, fixed is an integer quantity with a virtual radix point. If you represent latitude or longitude with a six digit integer, your maximum resolution is 1.5 second. To get better than that, you can give an integer as a Northing and an Easting as is done in the UTM system. That only works if you have a grid reference, which was not specified.
What DARPA really means by "fixed" is %.6f in C. This is a double precision number, not an int.

item.title: ITFR00
item.author: Tyler Folsom
item.description:
Posted by: Tyler Folsom to Rules:ITFR00

Did anyone notice the change to the RNDF format that DARPA made on December 1, 2006? Latitudes and longitudes for waypoints are no longer given in degrees. They are to be six digit integers in the ITRF00 reference frame. The sample_RNDF supplied by DARPA has not been updated to this format and no example of it is provided. DARPA requires that the site visit RNDF (due March 16, 2006) use this format.
From what I have been able to find on this format (International Terrestrial Reference Frame of 2000), it appears to use UTM (Universal Transverse Mercator) coordinates. However, UTM requires a grid reference and there is none in the RNDF format. The RNDF format specifies negative numbers for longitude, but this is not done in UTM. Northing is a seven digit integer, not the six digits specified.
Does anyone understand ITRF00?

The A20-MC is:

item.title: Wireless Emergency Stop System
item.author: torctech
item.description:
Posted by: torctech to Qualification Process:Wireless Emergency Stop System


As most of you know, DARPA will NOT be supplying an emergency stop system for testing or sites visits and is requiring each team to provide a wireless emergency stop system for site visits (see DARPA Site Visit Guidelines). TORC Technologies is offering the SafeStop™ ES-200 wireless emergency stop system at a 28% discount, to DARPA Urban Challenge teams. The SafeStop™ ES-200 is a multilevel, wireless emergency stop system for unmanned and autonomous vehicles. The handheld transmitter controls independent pause and stop relays, and provides visual and audible feedback of the state of the relays and communication link. The transmitter will operate for over 30 hours on a single charge, and can be used up to 5 miles away from the vehicle mounted receiver. The 4” x 4” x 2” receiver includes a serial data output in addition to the two 5A relays. With 32 channels to choose from, multiple SafeStop™ systems can be used simultaneously.

http://share.torctech.com/SafeStop/ES-200 _Flyer.pdf

Call us today at 540-443-9262 ext 1 to order your SafeStop™ ES-200 wireless emergency stop system. Good luck to each team in the DARPA Urban Challenge!


[Edited on 6/15/2007]

Attachments:

item.title: HMR3500 True Point Magnetic Compass from Point Research Corporation
item.author: Tommy
item.description:
Posted by: Tommy to Technology:HMR3500 True Point Magnetic Compass from Point Research Corporation

I'm using the HMR3000 with success. Calibrating the device only took an hour and the results have been reasonably accurate and responsive. I just use the RS232 interface. I don't use LabVIEW for anything since it is unnessary overhead on top of the very fast real-time features of XP. My software is multi-threaded Microsoft C++ and rides down on the drive shaft such that even though I do 2 dimensional laser processing 20 times a second accurate to 1 inch at 80 feet, satellite, HMR3000, actuator and stepping motor control for the brakes, gas, gear and steering, the CPU is busy only 15% of the time.

Good luck,
Tommy Spurrier

item.title: RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?
item.author: Virginia
item.description:
Posted by: Virginia to Rules:RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?

"It would seem to me that it would be better to perform fine-tuned lane following using visual systems on the vehicle that do not depend on external signals. What do other people think of this rule?"

If I were a guerilla and I knew that an autonomous vehicle was using visual cues as its primary means for lane following, it seems like a can of paint would be all that I need in order to paint over existing lines and paint some new lines that would run a convoy off the road.

item.title: site-visit site
item.author: Ivar Schoenmeyr
item.description:
Posted by: Ivar Schoenmeyr to Qualification Process:site-visit site

I took a drive out to Johannesburg this weekend. The streets are paved and grided perfectly, but unfortunately not wide enough. If I read the sitevisit requirement correctly one needs 2 lanes each 4.5 meters wide = 9m total width.

Good luck finding 4 'real' streets anywhere that intersects to form a 250 - 500 m loop and are 9m wide.

The only thing I can think of is to reserve 100 x 120 m portion of a large (stadium) parkinglot and stripe it with lanes for the event... (and have the vision system go crazy seeing all the striped parking spots)

item.title: site-visit site
item.author: arturomdn
item.description:
Posted by: arturomdn to Qualification Process:site-visit site

Steve - Yes, we used SwRI in 2005 and they were fantastic hosts. We would like to host the site visit in a place where we have done lots of testing, and therefore our first choice is to look for something closer. Our first inquiry into the private parking lot that I mentioned earlier has come back negative. It is a lot easier to find someone with the authority to say "no" than to find someone with the authority (and interest) to say "yes". The search continues.

item.title: EZ Magnetic Compass
item.author: arturomdn
item.description:
Posted by: arturomdn to Technology:EZ Magnetic Compass

A digital compass uses tilt compensation to estimate heading, and tilt is affected by acceleration/deceleration of the frame of reference.
See this article about how low cost devices estimate heading. Minor errors in heading can accumulate and result in big errors if you are using it to perform dead-reckoning in GPS denied situations.

http://www.ssec.honeywell.com/magnetic/da tasheets/lowcost.pdf

"ACCELERATION EFFECTS
Any acceleration of the compass will effect the tilt or
accelerometer outputs and will result in heading errors.
An aircraft making a turn will cause the tilt sensors to
experience the centripetal force in addition to gravity and
the compass heading will be in error. However, for most
applications the acceleration is small, or is in effect for a
short duration, making a magnetic compass a useful
navigation tool. Inertial reference systems would be the
solution for applications that can not tolerate these
heading errors. These systems would weigh, cost, and
consume power at least 10 times more than those of a
strapdown magnetic compass."

item.title: EMC
item.author: arturomdn
item.description:
Posted by: arturomdn to Miscellaneous:EMC

Fitting the vehicle with do-it-yourself drive-by-wire is not for the faint of heart. You might save money, but
you won't save time. Reading some of the technical papers from previous events can be helpful should you
decide to do it yourself. For a specific electric motor for steering actuator and pictures of how it was attached
to the steering shaft, see our team technical paper (click here to avoid annoying space in URL below):

http://www.darpa.mil/grandchallenge05/Tec hPapers/Austin_Robot_Technology.pdf

Several teams reported burnt steering motors/controllers prior to the site visits in 2005. Make sure you size
the motor properly. We decided to use a high torque (high current) motor with a 10:1 gear head, this allowed
the actuator to turn the wheels quickly even when the engine was off (no power steering). We also selected
a motor that had a built-in encoder and a controller. We were happy with our choice.

item.title: EMC
item.author: LeenSTL
item.description:
Posted by: LeenSTL to Miscellaneous:EMC

EMC has servo motors for steering, plus some parts of their system is electronic for automatic transmissions etc. If you just want to see the basics of a closed loop steering system you can go to the Robotek site and see if they still have the link for building a full size R/C car. It is short on details but shows an overview.

item.title: IMU's
item.author: Militoy
item.description:
Posted by: Militoy to Technology:IMU's

The caution I noted regarding Kalman filters related to the differences between firmware algorithms used in airborne IMUs and those designed for use in ground vehicle applications. For instance - PC Flight Systems makes a low-cost MEMS IMU called the eGYRO-XP, which is designed as a strap-on electronic gyro and EFIS module for General Aviation use. If installed onto a ground vehicle and calibrated, when the vehicle is moved into a pitched or rolled attitude and held static, the IMU’s firmware will within a few seconds “correct” the data baseline and establish a new “straight and level” baseline at the new attitude. The Kalman filter algorithm used is not designed to accurately interpret a long-term static pitch or roll condition – since those are not conditions encountered during normal flight dynamics. The data could be corrected by post-processing – but why not just select an IMU designed for ground vehicular applications?

As far as acceleration goes – a prudently-designed IMU made for vehicular applications should have a higher level of shock and vibration tolerance than one designed for flight dynamics – except perhaps a flight IMU designed for AUF or AIF environments, or similar.

item.title: IMU's
item.author: Marcel
item.description:
Posted by: Marcel to Technology:IMU's


@ Miltoy,
Most IMU's are excellent for ground vehicles, since there are less extra accelerations (other than gravity), that may make the reference for roll and pitch inaccurate. Some IMU manufacturers (such as Xsens.com) integrate IMU's with other sensors, such as vision, GPS and more. You can get specifications of these new products on request.

Kalman filtering is the most important part of an IMU, since most IMU manufacturers use the same MEMS sensors.

item.title: RNDF MDF Parser C/C++ Code
item.author: DaveB
item.description:
Posted by: DaveB to Technology:RNDF MDF Parser C/C++ Code

MarkIvin asks, "My input txt files still have tab characters, do I need to change them to blanks or some such thing"

Nope, the latest RNDF/MDF format definition (12/6/06) requires tab delimiters. See the Rules page.

It looks possible that your interpretation of the file name is different than the programmer's. The sample MDF lists the RNDF file name without a suffix, but the posted RNDF file name has a .txt suffix. My guess is that you left the .txt suffix on the file, but the programmer interprets the file name in the MDF literally, so it's looking for Sample_RNDF_Rev_1.2 rather than Sample_RNDF_Rev_1.2.txt

It seems like I remember DARPA addressing this naming problem, but I can't find it in the FAQ files. Personally, I think if they provide an RNDF file named Sample_RNDF_Rev_1.2.txt then that's what should be in the MDF, but maybe that's too much to ask. I suspect they only added the .txt suffix to simplify publishing it on the net, but sheesh!

Just smile

item.title: RNDF MDF Parser C/C++ Code
item.author: MarcIrvin
item.description:
Posted by: MarcIrvin to Technology:RNDF MDF Parser C/C++ Code

HI,

OKAY, I was able to get the strtok() deprecate thing bypassed with some help from someone on the C++ forum who had me add a define line.
#define _CRT_SECURE_NO_DEPRECATE 1

Unfortunately, that left me with one other error LNK2019. The error said it could not find the external reference to _WinMain@16. After research I was able to figure out how to tell the LINKer to replace /SUBSYSTEM:WINDOWS with /SUBSYSTEM:CONSOLE, and I was able to build an .exe, but I don't know if its working.

I know I can not complain about freeware, but when it came time to run the code I was guessing about the input and output I should see. Here are some of my experiments, none of which met with success. My input txt files still have tab characters, do I need to change them to blanks or some such thing. I just downloaded the files straight to the work directory.

What exactly is Usage: RNDF-MDF RNDFfile MDFfile trying to say?

c:\mvi>translater
Usage: RNDF-MDF RNDFfile MDFfile
PARSE ERROR: No RNDF file name.
c:\mvi>translater RNDF-MDF c:\mvi\Sample_RNDF.txt c:\mvi\Sample_MDF.txt
PARSE ERROR: Could not open RNDF file.
c:\mvi>translater RNDF-MDF Sample_RNDF.txt Sample_MDF.txt
PARSE ERROR: Could not open RNDF file.
c:\mvi>translater Sample_RNDF.txt Sample_MDF.txt

item.description:

I can't get the parser to compile on the newest MS version on C++ because strtok() is deprecated. That is MS VS C++ Express which I was able to trial for free. Can someone give me an .exe or point me at some freeware C++ compiler that will build the parser? This is what I posted on the MSDN C++ Forum...

"I have a program reportedly compiled with VS C++ V6 that I need to compile, (no using the new VS C++ Express. The only major error message preventing the build come from deprecation of the strtok() commands in the program. I have searched all over the internet, and gotten advice to swith to strtok_s or turnoff the deprecation. I can't find a step by step detail instruction on how to turnoff deprecate in VS C++ Express, nor can I find any step by step conversion instructions for a replacement command that works. For example, if I do what the compiler says, change the strtok to strtok_s or _r even the resulting build does not even recognize the commands. I am hoping that this is a simple matter for the experts among you. I just don't understand why I can not find a cookbook solution to avoid posting a question. "

Also, another angle I am working is I have installed a Fedora Core 6 Linux machine under VMware Beta . But I don't have a chops yet for doing a build compiles on it yet. Work in progress.

item.title: Greater Autonomy
item.author: pgrayson@aimagic.org
item.description:
Posted by: pgrayson@aimagic.org to Rules:Greater Autonomy


In this race DARPA does not plan to use the e-stop to prevent collisions, only to prevent the vehicles from leaving the race area. They are going to let the vehicles do what they do to see what that is. Considering the NY TAXI driver behavior required and illustrated at the Participants Conference, that any vehicle that is not prepared for contact is not prepared for the race. One of the rules is "no external fuel tanks" in this race, which should be taken as a hint from the race officials. TerraMax is is this race. Expect to meet it at the interesections and be prepared to avoid it. The new version is one axel shorter. Be concerned about the smallest vehicle too. You don't want to get the little one caught in your vehicles teeth and have it stop the two of you. Shock to the electronics may be from the side this race. Last race it was from below.

item.description:

item.title: Greater Autonomy
item.author: Militoy
item.description:
Posted by: Militoy to Rules:Greater Autonomy

I got the impression from the first site visit that if your own vehicle were to contact another, that would be the end of the race for your team. If another team's vehicle were to strike yours, a 5 MPH bumper (standard on all US-sold vehicles) would help prevent some of the damage - but only if the other vehicle were to contact at under 5 MPH - and only if the contact was directly on the bumper. If you're going to rely on protection from "springy bumpers", better put them 360 degrees around the vehicle! And - better hope that "Terramax" isn't involved in the accident!

item.title: Greater Autonomy
item.author: pgrayson@aimagic.org
item.description:
Posted by: pgrayson@aimagic.org to Rules:Greater Autonomy


From the acceleration spike readings I have seen for solid contact with anything, springy bumpers, shock absorbing bumpers look like a very good idea for protecting your vehicle and its contents. Model T bumpers were spring bumpers good for 5 mph crashes.

item.title: RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?
item.author: Salty
item.description:
Posted by: Salty to Rules:RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?

Since DARPA seems to want safe operation within California law, it seems these should take precedance. Humans make judgements. In an urban environemnt simple rule following will probably get a vehicle in trouble.

item.title: Orphans
item.author: Salty
item.description:
Posted by: Salty to Rules:Orphans

Large vehicles like semi-tractor trailers are allowed to "violate" lane restrictions and markings in order to make turns that could not be done otherwise. There is a practicle interpration element to enforcement. The standard used is to do so safely. In order to make right turns, the vehicle may start in the right lane, swing into the left lane and then start turning right coming into the oposing traffic lane before ending up in the right lane. An interesting judgenet situation occurs when another vehicle obstructs the turning vehicle. Since these vehicles do not have the abilityu to see well to the rear, it is unsafe to back up without calling the police:-( A judgement has to be made about waiting or trying to manuver.

I believe our sensor team has selected the Honeywell TruePoint as a backup to our fluxgate/FOA based-IMU. We were using a KVH C100 previously, and I haven’t worked with the Honeywell unit myself, but according to the manual, you need to use NI-VISA for serial communications. If you’re using LabVIEW, the Example Programs under the Help section describes a Basic Serial Write and Read routine, which should help you. The specific serial communication protocol should be outlined in the Honeywell manual and programming guide.

item.title: Selecting a Microcontroller/Embedded Computer for Mobile Robotics
item.author: Militoy
item.description:
Posted by: Militoy to Technology:Selecting a Microcontroller/Embedded Computer for Mobile Robotics

Your selection of a specific embedded controller should take into consideration the experience and background of the students, as well as the user-friendliness of available support materials. Better to start them out with a simple stamp controller, or a lower-end micro like a Rabbit 3000, and then build in functions until they outgrow its capabilities - than to frustrate them with too much complexity at first. The PIC line of controllers from Microchip would be on the next level up from the Z80-evolved Rabbits, and are extremely well supported.

item.title: Selecting a Microcontroller/Embedded Computer for Mobile Robotics
item.author: Bill
item.description:
Posted by: Bill to Technology:Selecting a Microcontroller/Embedded Computer for Mobile Robotics

The nice thing about PSoC is the new software for the new person or the engineer that just wants to try something simple as a test. Drag and drop blocks and the program writes your code.
We are currently working with that team in writing blocks that will fit our robot development kit.



PSoC Express(TM) enables the engineer to go from concept to embedded ASIC in one hour or less." PSoC Express is a free, code-free, visual design tool. Designers have access to libraries of temp. sensors, switches, potentiometers, FETs, fans, and more. This tool also auto-generates a data sheet, schematic, and bill of materials. Plus, you can easily port designs to full-featured PSoC Designer. PSoC Express is free and can be downloaded at www.cypress.com/psocexpress.

item.title: Selecting a Microcontroller/Embedded Computer for Mobile Robotics
item.author: Militoy
item.description:
Posted by: Militoy to Technology:Selecting a Microcontroller/Embedded Computer for Mobile Robotics

Further to above – My comment isn’t intended to impugn Bill’s suggestion in any way. The Cypress PSoC flash micros are robust products, and the one he suggests has lots of I/O, which is helpful for robotic applications. Only “BSM ACS” knows what level his students are starting from, and it’s been my experience that optimum success will result through starting with the basics, and then building upon that base. Whichever processor you choose, the evaluation/development kit available for it will be a good investment. If size isn’t too much of an issue, the evaluation board may even wind up as part of your final robot.

item.title: Selecting a Microcontroller/Embedded Computer for Mobile Robotics
item.author: Bill
item.description:
Posted by: Bill to Technology:Selecting a Microcontroller/Embedded Computer for Mobile Robotics

We build autonomous robots for S&R. The micro we use on our smaller robots is made by Cypress Semiconductor. I would use the CY8C29866. The software is a free download, and they have education programs. The controller has both analog and digital capability. There is also a wireless interface for data transfer. Contact me if you have other questions.

item.title: Selecting a Microcontroller/Embedded Computer for Mobile Robotics
item.author: BSM ACS
item.description:
Posted by: BSM ACS to Technology:Selecting a Microcontroller/Embedded Computer for Mobile Robotics

(This is not directly related to the Grand Challenge, but I'm not sure who else to ask.)

My question, in short: is there an embedded computer that would be accessible enough for high school students?

Here's the background information:
For the third year, our high school class is designing a robot for the RoboCup Search & Rescue competition. The primary software tasks on the robot involve creating maps of the disaester area and executing low-level autonomy. Our software expectations are significantly lower than the universities participating: we are not trying to implement SLAM, machine vision, or autonomous victim identification.

We would like to integrate readings from encoders, IMUs, proximity sensors, a digital compass, and data from our laser scanner (the Hokuyo URG-04LX.) Our robot also has a thermal imager and several video cameras, however we are not attempting to integrate this data into the software (we may end up simply broadcasting it directly back to the control station.)

Ideally, we would implement a GUI on the control station computer that displays sensor data and video feeds. We would like to use joysticks and a keyboard to control the robot.

I hit the 1500 character limit, but I have more to say. Sorry for the diversion, thanks for your help, and good luck in the Urban Challenge.

item.title: AutonoSys Announces World's First Lidar Video Cameras
item.author: Autonosys1
item.description:
Posted by: Autonosys1 to Vendor/Suppliers:AutonoSys Announces World's First Lidar Video Cameras

Ottawa, Canada October 23 2006 – Unique New Cameras Capture Full 3D Images At High Speed.
LIDAR systems measuring approximately 10,000 ranges/second in a line-scan are commonly available. The AutonoSys lidar video cameras measure ranges 50 times faster, at 500,000 ranges/second. With this amount of data per second, it becomes possible to produce a full 3D image of a scene at video rates of 5-10 frames a second. AutonoSys' camera has a 30° x 90° field of view, with 144 x 480 pixel resolution, updated at 5 frames/second. Range to every pixel in the frame is measured to an accuracy of a few mm. Field of view, resolution and frame rate can all be customized to meet demands of the application. Applications for the new cameras include obstacle and terrain sensing for autonomous ground vehicles, improved recognition of threats in security monitoring systems, and any other application where fast capture of 3D data is required.The lidar video camera uses a rangefinder developed by Z+F Gmbh, a manufacturer with over 20 years experience in the lidar field. The optical scanning mechanism and custom electronics in the camera was developed by AutonoSys Inc., an Ottawa based high tech company specializing in systems and sub-systems for Autonomous Vehicles. For more information contact Rob Bruce, AutonoSys, phone (613) 277 0980. Visit www.autonosys.com for videos, images and product information.

[Edited on 10/31/2006]

item.title: Simulator
item.author: Tyler Folsom
item.description:
Posted by: Tyler Folsom to Technology:Simulator

The thread on Open Source is quite active. This is in some ways a reply to it, but I started a new thread for increased visibility.

The Urban Challenge is primarily a software challenge. This differs from the 2005 challenge. Since software is the prime component, a driving simulator becomes crucial and is a prime candidate for open source. There is a robot simulator for Urban Search and Rescue (USAR) on Source Forge. This is a mod to Unreal Tournament (UT) and runs on Windows or Linux. I have done a first cut of a driving simulator by modding the USAR simulator. Future plans will incorporate Unwheel, a mod to Unreal Tournament that makes it a driving game. This is not free software since it requires buying one or more copies of the UT game. Other than that, it is potentially open source.

I am team leader for Thunderbird Robotics at University of British Columbia. Making the simulator publicly available will require consensus of the team.

Check out:
http://sourceforge.net/projects/usarsim
MOAST on sourceforge
www.ubcthunderbird.com
www.tfolsom.com

item.title: Is the Urban Challenge offcial???
item.author: LeenSTL
item.description:
Posted by: LeenSTL to Urban Challenge Final Event:Is the Urban Challenge offcial???

Here is the pseudo-pseudocode for St Louis driving, where only rain snow or ice slows (some of ) the traffic down. They don't let anyone into their lane, yield at yield signs, stop at stop signs, or ever slow down to get behind another vehicle when changing lanes:

If another vehicle detected pulling into my lane: speed up, honk horn, flip off
If stop sign present: ignore
If vehicle ahead stopped at stop sign: honk horn, flip off
If yield sign detected: full speed ahead
If I need to change lanes: no turn signal, speed up to beat any vehicle next to me, change lane
If precipitation
case rain: slow to crawl
case ice:
If (4wd)
drive too fast, spin
Else
slow to crawl

Yah, I've had all kinds of drivers (soccer moms seem to be especially bad here) speed up to cut me off, and even honk when they had to stop behind me at a stop sign. The driving theme seems to be "You had the nerve to use turn signals? !#@$% It's MY road, stay out of my lane! Wait, I want to be in your lane, I'll speed up and just drift over."

Jenness Simler, a committee aide on the House Armed Services Committee, said DARPA can still give out cash prizes as long as it works with its boss.

item.title: Charge 12 volt batteries from 24 volt source
item.author: Militoy
item.description:
Posted by: Militoy to Miscellaneous:Charge 12 volt batteries from 24 volt source

I've seen a few 24V systems on off-road vehicles that were kluged together successfully using a pair of ex-automotive alternators. Just make sure you isolate the housing of the topside alternator above system ground, as most alternators have the negative of their hexbridge tied right to ground at the housing. No reason to make more sparks and smoke than neccessary!

item.title: Charge 12 volt batteries from 24 volt source
item.author: sapper023
item.description:
Posted by: sapper023 to Miscellaneous:Charge 12 volt batteries from 24 volt source

This IS odd but for your humor and my self i could
rewind the alternator 2 of the alternator windings for 12 volt charging ( 15 to 18 volts ) put a big post rectifier capacitor on the remaining only 24 coil left ( diode or ) the rotor winding controll signals from separate regulators inderectly fed through relays controlled by the regulators and use a relay to disable output of the system on what ever branch that did not need charge .
really quick note !
just from parts I have on hand yes I have the 4 additional diodes and relays that can handel 100 amps each
a 12 volt relay and 24 volt relay ( if noise was a problem I could use a chopper type of regulator made from an old wheel chair speed controller )
this would be a verry electricly noisy solution
only small capactor needed on the 12 volt side as it dumps into refrigeration system batteries which can usualy handel noise
the really inportant thing is to manage the batteries properly
kids do not try this stunt at home
of corse now that I have a metal lathe I could just make a custom alternator with 2 alternators on the same shaft and this would be 2 separate charging systems and would be about 20 to 30 percent bigger
you need to sum the electrical watts for proper signal to engine throttle controll which is powerplant system related in difficulty
for engine spin up put a delay on the regulator rotor current and use the regulator signal to engine summed without delay

item.author: TravisT
item.description:
Posted by: TravisT to Technology:Where's the Open Source Grand Challenge Entry?

This is the perfect thread to announce “R” Junk Works “Smart
Wheelchair” project.

People like you are
the right people to work with this type of technology.

The project has been
created to improve the quality of life for the handicapped.

The types of projects your working on, like interfacing
to servos, terrain following and autonomous controls are directly
applicable.

You are encouraged to
download our freely available open source software to get a greater
understanding of how we have applied autonomous robot technology for the
handicapped.

I will have to say that it
has personally been one of my most satisfying things I have ever done in my
life and the most fun with applying robotic concepts I have ever worked
with.

Maybe it will be for you as well.




It’s all open source and may be a start on your Urban
Challenge entry.

http://www.rjunkworks.com/swc/swc.html


PS-Trevor, KNetX is my wife and my own
contracting company that has a business license here is Palmdale California and does Contract Engineering Work.
“R” Junk Works is a non-business geeky robot
club we formed here in Lancaster/Palmdale to have fun and compete in various
robot style events.

AgentWare provides advanced software development services in the following areas:

- Vision systems (both our own software and Cognex sensors)

- Mission critical, 100% uptime software

- Computer controlled vehicles and machines

Our people developed the computer controls and recognition systems for one of the "Big Three" automakers' proving grounds, as one example.

item.title: Charge 12 volt batteries from 24 volt source
item.author: windpower
item.description:
Posted by: windpower to Miscellaneous:Charge 12 volt batteries from 24 volt source


I was wondering if you could use two 12 volt alternators to charge a 24 volt battery bank via connecting one alternator to the first half of the bank and the second alternator to the second half.

I currently have one 100 amp 12 volt alternator that I got pretty cheap several years ago ($79.00) from J.C. Whiteney and would like to build a wind generator, but would like it to be in the 2500 watt range. So I figured I would need at least a 12 foot diameter blade (I will probably use 15' to offsett resistance due to having to gear it up to 6000 rpm in a 30mph wind) and might be able to use another alternator identical to the first to charge a bank of batteries.

Any suggestions on this plan are welcome......Thanks

item.title: Potential Urban Challenge Practice Site
item.author: SwRI
item.description:
Posted by: SwRI to Miscellaneous:Potential Urban Challenge Practice Site

Southwest Research Institute (SwRI) in San Antonio, Texas, is exploring the possibility of offering a realistic practice site for use by teams preparing for the Urban Challenge. The site would be available to all Urban Challenge teams on a pre-scheduled basis. The site would support all of the basic and advanced events outlined in the “Rules” and other pertinent documents.

This would be a private undertaking, with no official relationship to DARPA or the Urban Challenge Program. Further, SwRI is not affiliated with any team.

Our intent is to offer use of the practice site at “no-cost” to the UC teams, and to offset our costs by obtaining outside sponsors.

If your team would like more information on this potential Urban Challenge practice site, please send an email to dawn.domaschk@swri.org.

[Edited on 10/5/2006]

Igor.

item.title: Track B Funding?
item.author: westcoastwatch
item.description:
Posted by: westcoastwatch to Miscellaneous:Track B Funding?

Assumed prize money authorization was not going to be extended - what are you talking about? DARPA originally announced the competition with a statement about prize money - three main prizes (2 million, 500 thou, and 250 thou plus incentive prizes for Track B participants who were accepted into the NQE ($50,000) and then into the competition itself ($100,000). They attracted 250 people to their workshop in Washington based on these carrots. Then they "announced" at that workshop that there might not be any prizes, but they were working on it. I understand they only learned about the wording in the bill about two days before the workshop. It was stated that the situation would be "resolved" one way or another over the summer. The Track A awardees were supposed to be announced in September - the announcement was made on Oct 2nd. I suspect that part of the delay was due to an attempt to get congressional approval for the prize money. So now without making a formal statement about the change, they simply ignore the original PR, yet they leave it up on their site since it is a mmatter of record. I suggest that there will only be 11 teams entered into the event as it is very difficult to raise sposnsorship support without the incentive of a monetary prize at the end. Those who waited for Track B are out of luck. Those who entered Track A and were not selected are also out of luck.
The NASA Centennial Challenges suddenly look much more attractive.

item.title: Track B Funding?
item.author: DGC Vet
item.description:
Posted by: DGC Vet to Miscellaneous:Track B Funding?

The 10/2 article on cnn.com about the UGC mentioned the top 3 prizes: $2M, $500K and $250K. It also states that other teams (Track B) will not be "subsidized". http://www.cnn.com/2006/TECH/10/02/robot. challenge.ap/index.html
My team applied for Track A and did not make the cut after we competed in the first 2 Challenges.



[Edited on 10/3/2006]

item.title: Track B Funding?
item.author: kayakmike
item.description:
Posted by: kayakmike to Miscellaneous:Track B Funding?

I don't think anyone assumed prize money authorization was going to be extended (at least we didn't). In fact, we assumed it was non-existent until we heard that authorization would be extended.

DARPA didn't arbitrarily set the event to late October - early November. They knew when funding was going to expire. If authorization was not extended, then DARPA saved themselves $2.75 million.

Regardless, DARPA always reserved the right to change the rules at any point in the competition. Prize money could have disappeared at any time. For that matter, prize money could re-appear at any time also (hypothetically). Or the entire event could be cancelled.

Don't count on the event date to change. There are 11 well funded teams that would complain if their contract/grant were jeopardized by a compressed schedule. 11 DARPA supported teams will have much more influence on DARPA than teams that DARPA did not deem worthy enough for funding.

The interesting point I've noticed is that the removal of prize money was quietly revealed without any mention in today's press release. AP is running a story how 11 teams are competing for prize money. That significant tid-bit wasn't mentioned in the press release.

item.title: Track B Funding?
item.author: westcoastwatch
item.description:
Posted by: westcoastwatch to Miscellaneous:Track B Funding?

We have been told categorically that DARPA will not be making any prize money awards to anyone who competes - neither Track A nor Track B. Not sure why anyone who didn't get a DARPA Grant under Track A would want to participate. Furthermore the fact that there are several documents on the site that state there will be prize money appears to me to be contradictory and perhaps illegal. How many people attended the workshop in Washington under the assumption that significant prize money would be awarded?

Seems like a misrepresentation to me!

item.title: New(er) SICK Sensors
item.author: Jeff_Wuendry_SICK
item.description:
Posted by: Jeff_Wuendry_SICK to Technology:New(er) SICK Sensors

Hi Jon,
I'll briefly describe the 2-D TOF products that SICK is offering for the 2007 DARPA Urban Challenge.

(1018028) LMS291-S05 180 degree FOV, 30m @ 10% reflectivity, 75 Hz scan frequency, 0.25-0.5-1.0 adjustable angular resolution (53.3-26.6,13.3 ms time base) 38.4 and 500kB serial

(1025329) LMS291-S14 same as above except: 90 degree FOV, 0.5 fixed angular resolution, 13.3 ms fixed time base

(1028941) LD-LRS1000 360 FOV, 80m @ 10%, 5-10Hz scan, 0.125-1.5 angular resolution, Ethernet, CAN, RS-232

LD-OEM is a general platform for the LD series. LD-Galileo was the pre-production name for the LD-LRS.

Jeff

I think most teams would be willing to give up a month of development time if the race was held on Saturday, September 29, 2007 instead of Nov 3, 2007, if it meant that the race could be held for prizes instead of trophies. item.title: Archytas wooden pigeon
item.author: Ivar Schoenmeyr
item.description:
Posted by: Ivar Schoenmeyr to Miscellaneous:Archytas wooden pigeon

Thanks for the helpful hints. Her research also concluded that it most likely used some form of 'rocket propulsion'. We are tempted to build a prototype using a copper reaction chamber into which we suspend a waterbaloon. The reactionchamber is then partially enclosed in a bird carved out of wood which in turn is suspended on a wire. The metal is then heated with a fixed blowtorch, we step back and watch what happens. (The test should probably be conducted outdoors).. Ivar

item.title: Archytas wooden pigeon
item.author: Militoy
item.description:
Posted by: Militoy to Miscellaneous:Archytas wooden pigeon

There is quite a bit of info published on Archytas' pigeon - Google Scholar is one good source. Most sites identify it as an aeolipile. Being a rocket-type project, I suspect that building and demonstrating a working model would be out of the question. I would gather as much info from Google Scholar as I could, and from that point on, let your daughter use her imagination. After all, her guess as to its actual shape may be as good as any other would-be historian's!

item.title: IMU's
item.author: Militoy
item.description:
Posted by: Militoy to Technology:IMU's

If keeping the system price down is more important than absolute precision, you’re likely looking at a MEMS system, rather than a fiber-optic based one. PC Flight Systems, MEMSense, and Xsens all have MEMS IMU’s available. Just make sure the Kalman Filter algorithm used is set up for a ground vehicle, rather than for flight dynamics.

item.title: Lane Detection System for Autonomous Vehicles
item.author: AutoCommute
item.description:
Posted by: AutoCommute to Vendor/Suppliers:Lane Detection System for Autonomous Vehicles

AutoCommute is making our Lane Detection System available to DARPA Urban Challenge teams. Developed specifically for urban navigation, our system detects lane markings such as lane markers, cross walks and stop lines.

The Lane Detection System can be used with human drivers to provide lane departure warnings, or can be used with autonomous systems to provide lane marking positions with respect to vehicle position for precise vehicle navigation.

We realize that one size doesn’t fit all for this type of system, so sensor arrangements can be customized to each team’s needs.

Information on the system is available on our web site (http://www.autocommute.com/LDS.htm). Feel free to contact us for additional information based on your team’s specific needs.

Yours sincerely,

AutoCommute
info@autocommute.com


[Edited on 9/18/2006]

item.title: Archytas wooden pigeon
item.author: Steve
item.description:
Posted by: Steve to Miscellaneous:Archytas wooden pigeon

I do not know that the shape is the important point, but NASA seems to have the clearest description that I found.

http://quest.arc.nasa.gov/space/teachers/ rockets/history.html

However, if you search on the Archytas, everyone seems to have a different description of what he flew. Some say a clay pigeon. NASA in particular indicates a wooden pigeon. One said it was probably a kite (though that site seems alone in that opinion). Most do say it was steam powered and and flew on a suspended wire (i.e. it propelled itself, but did not actually fly in the conventional sense) and could fly several hundred yards. But I do not think anyone actually knows what it looked like as the description comes from an author 300 years after the event.

I do not know that that gives you any more then you already had, but good luck.

item.title: Archytas wooden pigeon

item.title: Where's the Open Source Grand Challenge Entry?
item.author: Trevor Brown
item.description:
Posted by: Trevor Brown to Technology:Where's the Open Source Grand Challenge Entry?

The Sand Storm team also? I did not think you could be on
more then one team. I guess some can just get around.

I have looked over may places on the web and found some noble efforts, code snippets, cool videos, and even some
references of teams selling their vehicles on Ebay, but no real complete example system. The best spot I have been able to find for any real technical data that might be useful are the published Technical Reports.
They are all very scholarly and interesting but they mostly contain
just overviews of the designs and no real specifics on implementation. Cant
says I blame them with two million dollars at stake after all. Perhaps that is
the crux of the problem and why there is no Open Source entry as yet.

Trevor

item.title: Where's the Open Source Grand Challenge Entry?
item.author: Militoy
item.description:
Posted by: Militoy to Technology:Where's the Open Source Grand Challenge Entry?

I hadn't heard of a "Sand Storm" team, and wasn't trying to make that connection - I was referring to a local buggy shop (Sandstormers) that has supported or sponsored both teams. Since both teams also listed as a sponser the ultralight aircraft company where Rjunkworks was located - I am making a wild guess that Rjunkworks has been reorganized into a new team. As far as Open Source entry goes - I can't imagine any team that puts in a serious effort will willingly share their best ideas with prospective competitors. We view this competition the way we view any conventional race - You spend $4 million, for a chance to win $2 million and a shot at $20 million in contracts.

item.title: Charge 12 volt batteries from 24 volt source
item.author: Militoy
item.description:
Posted by: Militoy to Miscellaneous:Charge 12 volt batteries from 24 volt source

I would direct you to our own website, but the chargers we make are for military applications only – quite expensive and not usually available in lots of less than 10. You might consider using a multi-winding dual-voltage alternator like those made by MBP, or even a 24V input inverter, like a Dimensions Unlimited model, running a 12V 3-state charger. Dimensions even makes models with smart chargers built-in - I'll bet they would be willing to build you a 24V model, with a 12V charger wired up to the inverter output.

Militoy - Thanks for the heads up, but I already know that and I have taken it into account. Right now I just need to know if it is possible to use the 24volt alt to charge the 12volt batteries. You speak of a 3 stage charger that can take the 24volt input and charge at 12volt. Can you provide a link? This type of charger I have not been able to find - or I'm looking in the wrong places.

The "cartoon" is just a simplified diagram of the system. The currect 24volt system is regulated by a 3 stag alternator regulator, If I can use the same alternator to charge the AGMs without effecting the current system, then I would use appropriate means to protect the AGMs.

Thanks


[Edited on 8/30/2006]

item.title: Charge 12 volt batteries from 24 volt source
item.author: Militoy
item.description:
Posted by: Militoy to Miscellaneous:Charge 12 volt batteries from 24 volt source

I haven’t had a chance to look over the cartoon of your system, but here are a few notes on your charging issue:
AGM batteries need to be charged using a different set of current/voltage/temperature parameters than flooded lead-acid or gel cells. Simply bulk charging them like you might a flooded lead-acid bank can cause AGM batteries to explode under certain (unfortunate) circumstances. Charging cycles should be controlled in accordance with the battery manufacturer’s recommendations. The safest way to charge AGMs, and to assure their long life, is to use a 3 or 4-state charger, with temperature monitoring of your battery bank. The charger should be set up for "undercharge", "bulk charge", "overcharge" (optional), and "float charge". Look for a 3 or 4-state 12V charger that’s programmable for AGMs, and set up to run off of 24V. There should be commercial versions available (ours are for military applications, and fairly expensive). You will save $ if you undersize the charger capacity a bit, and put up with a slower charge rate.

item.title: Charge 12 volt batteries from 24 volt source
item.author: DaveB
item.description:
Posted by: DaveB to Miscellaneous:Charge 12 volt batteries from 24 volt source

Thoughts

The alternator must charge the batteries while delivering full load

Charging load might be eliminated by precharging batteries,
but then why would you need such large batteries?

200 A of 12 V uses only abt 100 A from the 24 V system

24 V equipment is smaller, & uses smaller wires than 12 V (1/2 the amps)
Could you change any of your load to 24 V?

The only reason for separate batteries is usually to reserve power
to start the motor -- a battery that won't be drained by "hotel" load.

It's a bad idea, for battery life, to charge at more than half its capacity.
That is, don't charge a 100 A Hr battery at more than 50 A

Complicated battery networks can make the above difficult to prevent.

If you're sure the alternator is 270 A at 24 V, it's probably plenty big enough,
but if it were actually 12 V, and used the equalizer to power the 24 V, then maybe not.

Equalizers, like inverters, use electronics that fail if overloaded, and sometimes if not,
so a more reliable system may be to add a 12 V alternator, and simplify the battery network

You could upload that schematic by clicking the "Attach File" button at the top of the window,
or just describe it, e.g. "24 V alternator to two batteries in series. 24-12 V equalizer from 24 V
to two batteries in parallel. 20 A of 24 V load. 50 A of 12 V load.

Why DO you need such large batteries?

item.title: Charge 12 volt batteries from 24 volt source
item.author: Jassper
item.description:
Posted by: Jassper to Miscellaneous:Charge 12 volt batteries from 24 volt source

We are adding (6) 12 volt 8D AGM type batteries rated at 255 Ahr for a total of 1530 Amp hours. The main charging will be from two 2500 watt inverter/chargers each capable of charging at 125 amps. Why so much power? Because our clientele does not know the meaning of "power conservation". They expect to be able to run everything regardless if they are driving, plugged into shore, or dry camping. My main concern is the fact that one of the (3) 1500btu air conditioners can be used while driving. The Air conditioner pulls about 18 amps AC while cooling. This equates to 180 amps DC at a 10:1 ratio out of the inverters. I realize not much charge will actually be going into the batteries and we will be using a Drop out relay to disconnect the Air Conditioner if the battery voltage becomes to low. The Inverters are also backed up by a 20Kwh diesel generator, if the power consumption is above a set point for an extended time the generator automatically starts – IF the customer has turned that feature on. Why the customers won't use the generator to run all 3 airs while driving is beyond my understanding of the rice and famous.

I don't have the schematics with me. I will get them on Monday and attach them along with other specifications and show what we want to do to the system. I have attached a simple drawing of the basic configuration. I'll post more info tomorrow. Thanks again

Jassper

Attachments:
H3-45 Chargeing system.dwf (1Kb)

item.title: Charge 12 volt batteries from 24 volt source
item.author: sapper023
item.description:
Posted by: sapper023 to Miscellaneous:Charge 12 volt batteries from 24 volt source

A rough note sorry if I skip around on subjects .
This is a common upgrade problem of recreational vehical , vehical computer instalation , large robot desighns ( mine at least ) and car sterio power systems and your proposed idea may work in a few situations but may be troublsome if the system is not understood before upgrade so you are wise to ask around .
Without a schimatic of your system and proposed system I would hesitate to comment as there are several issues of charging system style , safety , economy and practicality .
I also would not load an alternator more if the power plant was desighned to have that alternator as there is a general mechanic practice of using large alternators to offset heat and peak load requirements issues and may need a wider belt or more belts and/or cooling and/or external diodes to actualy deliver full ratings .
If you do not want me to evaluate your system take your system to a recreational vehical or industrial truck wiring specialist and request quotes or information on your alternatives , as there are manual and automatic systems to choose from as well as lifespan and matinance issues they could also see if there will be belt and heat issues as it could take me a month to find my reference material on belts and pullies .
Could you provide a schematic of your system as I may only need a paragraph for response for the electrical issues .

item.title: Charge 12 volt batteries from 24 volt source
item.author: Jassper
item.description:
Posted by: Jassper to Miscellaneous:Charge 12 volt batteries from 24 volt source

Not really related to the Grand Challenge, but who better to ask than you guys!

Situation:
I have a 24 volt 270amp Delco alternator driven by a series 60 diesel engine. Now it is connected to the chassis system which is a 24 volt system, Four 12volt batteries wired in series-parallel for a 24volt bank using a 100amp Equalizer. The chassis system only requires about 60 to 70 amps, leaving me with about 200 amps unused. I have a second "House" system of Six 8D 12 volt AGM batteries wired in parallel, this system could demand up to 200 amps +.

Question:
I've never seen this done, but - Can I use the 24 volt alternator to charge the 12 volt batteries? I know the equalizer already splits it into 12 and 24 to charge the chassis batteries, would changing the 100 amp Equalizer to a 300 amp allow me to tap off the 12volt side to charge the house batteries? The House would be a much larger draw so I'm thinking that this would over load the chassis batteries.

Is there a way I can take advantage of this over size 24 volt alternator to charge a bank of 12 volt batteries?

Thanks

item.title: OBD2 vehicle data acquisition - J2534, CAN, J1850, ISO9141, SCI, etc
item.author: Brian
item.description:
Posted by: Brian to Vendor/Suppliers:OBD2 vehicle data acquisition - J2534, CAN, J1850, ISO9141, SCI, etc

We supply a variety of products to communicate with onboard computers in newer automobiles, heavy duty trucks, off road vehicles, and CAN in avation and aerospace. The CarDAQ-DV features embedded Linux on a 200MHZ processor, built-in wireless, wired ethernet, and support for all J2534-1 protocols including ISO15765 (CAN), J1850PWM (Ford SCP), J1850VPW (GM Class 2), ISO9141 (KWP2000), and Chrysler SCI. The embedded Linux platform allows developers to host applications on the CarDAQ-DV so it can operate without a PC connected. The CarDAQ-Plus has all of that functionality and adds 8 high resolution analog inputs, USB, J1939/J1708 suport, and two Compact Flash slots for the addition of up to 4GB of memory, GPS, or cellular modems.

Drew Technologies also has a licensable enhanced data library and API for 3rd party integration. The library and API allow programers to easily integrate vehicle data into their existing application without knowing automotive-specific protocols and diagnostics. This product will allow you to log events that happen on the vehicle bus, perform diagnostics, and collect real time paramaters such as PIDs, DPIDS, and DMRs from the automobile such as speed, rpm, ABS brake status, drive-by-wire sterring data, and more.

www.drewtech.com
bherron@drewtech.com

item.title: A harder course.
item.author: RobotGuy
item.description:
Posted by: RobotGuy to Technology:A harder course.

SICKs have their issues, but they are an order of magnitude cheaper than similarly capable sensors. Some of the teams (Stanford, CMU, Perceptek) have been using SICKs for years and have them pretty well down. The "dazzle" bit is a perfect example of how people in the know had no problems and people out of the know struggled mightily. Don't hesitate to ask these kinds of questions on the discussion boards as you can usually get answers from the old hands (particularly at the Universities).

item.title: New FAQ Responses
item.author: RobotGuy
item.description:
Posted by: RobotGuy to Rules:New FAQ Responses

Being street-legal isn't enough because this is a race. Moreover, it is like a race driven by chimps. Race vehicles are often expected to have additional safety measures, and DARPA is correct in requiring the same here. I can see why they are interested in non-chassis upgrades. For instance, Red Team's H1ghlander used a custom hydraulic steering system. Hydraulic steering is now used in some trucks but is illegal in several states. Electric drivetrains, hydraulic steering, and custom fuel tanks all could make the drive-by-wire problem easier, but introduce new safety issues. Ideally DARPA would let teams make any modifications then perform a safety inspection, but DARPA doesn't have the expertise for that.

item.title: INS+GPS for Urban Environments from Oxford Technical Solutions
item.author: OxfordTechnicalSolutions
item.description:
Posted by: OxfordTechnicalSolutions to Vendor/Suppliers:INS+GPS for Urban Environments from Oxford Technical Solutions

Navigation in Urban environments is challenging. But new features in our Inertial Navigation Systems (INS) make it simple and reliable:

* RT3000 algorithms used successfully by Gray, Terramax and CajunBot in the last GC

* Urban/Indoor Tracking GPS, so you will almost always have GPS

* Wheel speed input for dead-reckoning if GPS is unavailable

* Terrain Feature Updating - recognize features from the Route Network Definition File (stop signs, road edges) using vision/radar etc., send them to the INS and it updates the outputs, keeping you accurate for long periods of time even without GPS

* Quick operational capability, with installation, calibration and training completed in hours (not days)

Plus, this will be our lowest priced system

See www.oxts.com/option.asp?active_page_id=13 3
Contact Brent Rijnovean brent@brendelassociates.com
M: (313) 729-9898
T: (313) 278-1872

Background

Oxford Technical Solutions has been making commercial INS with GPS since 1998, has supplied nearly 200 systems worldwide and has a keen interest in Autonomous programs. We have supplied INS to many Autonomous programs such as the DARPA Grand Challenge, ABD Autonomous Robots, Volkswagen for their autonomous Golf 53+1 (just announced) plus several other car manufacturers.

item.title: Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge
item.author: LeenSTL
item.description:
Posted by: LeenSTL to Rules:Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge

In a real world scenario your product might be of use, but for this competiton in a "simulated urban environment" I think the route files must be followed.
The rules specify that route files (plus any data which can be derived from supplied maps etc) will be used, ie, existing signage may or not match the route files but the route files trump existing signage / street markings etc. This gives DARPA the flexibility to create their "simulated urban environment" on an existing training site or similar without having to have any signage present at all.

item.title: Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge
item.author: Patrick Andrews
item.description:
Posted by: Patrick Andrews to Rules:Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge

It seems to me that one of the main challenges for autonomous vehicles is, rightly, to be able to use existing road signage.
We have made this suggestion in connection with our software product SceneReader which is mentioned in the Vendors section (www.scenereader.com)...reliance on GPS or dead reckoning in any real Urban environment will surely not be sufficient/ meaningful?

item.title: A harder course.
item.author: ptrep
item.description:
Posted by: ptrep to Technology:A harder course.

I would be very surprised if someone wins the Urban Challenge with Sicks. Their limited range and wacky behavior, along with the most overly-complicated API I have every seen, all contribute to making them a poor choice for any autonomous vehicle application, especially one as difficult as the Urban Challenge. This is just my two cents. We used them last year, and we finished the race, but using them was like pulling teeth.

item.title: A harder course.
item.author: RJMason
item.description:
Posted by: RJMason to Technology:A harder course.

JN: But you're not going to win the Urban Challenge with SICK units. It's time to move up.

I respectfully disagree with John.

Some people said that SICK units were not good enough for the Grand Challenge, but in fact, they were perfectly adequate, as Stanford demonstrated.

SICK units should be even more adequate for the Urban Challenge, with its lower speed limit and mostly-paved environment. In my opinion, the Urban Challenge is not harder, at least not much harder, with respect to sensing. It is much harder with respect to planning. It will be won by the best planner, not necessarily by the best sensor.

I do not know the details of what is going on with this (and I would appreciate updates from DARPA when they have some), but as I have had similar questions I can add this.

1) What was said at the conference (if I remember correctly) was that they MAY have resolved things by the 4th of July.

2) Searching the Senate calender, it appears that starting on the 20th, the Senate is going to start (it is scheduled for at least two days) to vote on amendments to the Defense Appropriations Bill to try to resolve the differences with the House Bill.

3) When I search the House Bill, I cannot (I am not an expert on such things) find anything to do with this event -- but I assume it is buried in there somewhere (perhaps as an attachment).

4) The Congressional appropriations cycle is a long one.

I do not know if this helps, but it is what I could search out.

item.title: Where's the Open Source Grand Challenge Entry?
item.author: brianp
item.description:
Posted by: brianp to Technology:Where's the Open Source Grand Challenge Entry?

As other posters have pointed out, the Joint Architecture for Unmanned Systems is there, mature, and I strongly feel that it's the best platform for an open source Entry. The modular nature of JAUS really lends itself to sharing and collaborating on discrete components, perhaps designed specifically for a particular COTS part. Since there is a reference architecture to work from, there isn't a whole lot of room to squabble over design.

The OpenJAUS project is very much alive, with a parent project on sourceforge (http://openjaus.sourceforge.net/). There is a Java implementation available on java.net, which has been successfully deployed. I've also been working diligently on a C JAUS library, but there is still nothing in the sourceforge repository. If there is an interest in sharing and collaborating on JAUS components, I think the OpenJAUS project on sourceforge is an excellent candidate for a base project.

Brian Prodoehl

item.title: VIRGINIA CONFERENCE
item.author: RJMason
item.description:
Posted by: RJMason to Miscellaneous:VIRGINIA CONFERENCE

DaveB: Not only do I think a Geo Metro could have finished the two off-road challenges, but I doubt it would even have been a disadvantage, but some of those who've actually traveled those courses might disagree.

The first off-road challenge was actually pretty rough in places. I drove it in a serious 4x4 vehicle and at one point I managed to get temporarily stuck. Driving it in a Geo Metro might be theoretically possible, but I think would be a daunting experience even for a human driver.

I did not drive the second off-road course but it was reported to be less challenging.

item.title: Applanix - Commercial Off The Shelf INS/GPS Navigation For Autonomous Vehicles
item.author: John Nagle
item.description:
Posted by: John Nagle to Vendor/Suppliers:Applanix - Commercial Off The Shelf INS/GPS Navigation For Autonomous Vehicles

Spend the money and buy this, or the comparable Novatel system. You need the fibre optic heading gyro and the high precision inertial system. We (Team Overbot) went to the Grand Challenge with a lower-grade INS and no fibre optic heading gyro, and the 2 degree error from the lower grade systems was enough to cause serious problems. If you saw our runs, where the vehicle would try to get through a tight spot, stop, back up, reposition, and eventually get through, that was why - our heading info was just slightly off. That problem can be solved by throwing money at the problem.

item.title: Orphans
item.author: wolfbob
item.description:
Posted by: wolfbob to Rules:Orphans

The California code is:

21460. (a) When double parallel solid lines are in place, no person
driving a vehicle shall drive to the left thereof, except as
permitted in this section.
(b) When the double parallel lines, one of which is broken, are in
place, no person driving a vehicle shall drive to the left thereof,
except as follows:
(1) That the driver on that side of the roadway in which the
broken line is in place may cross over the double line or drive to
the left thereof when overtaking or passing other vehicles.
(2) As provided in Section 21460.5.
(c) Either of the markings as specified in subdivision (a) or (b)
does not prohibit a driver from crossing the marking when (1) turning
to the left at any intersection or into or out of a driveway or
private road, or (2) making a U-turn under the rules governing that
turn, and either of the markings shall be disregarded when authorized
signs have been erected designating offcenter traffic lanes as
permitted under Section 21657.
(d) Raised pavement markers may be used to simulate painted lines
described in this section when the markers are placed in accordance
with standards established by the Department of Transportation.

I have had two citations that show they do enforce it.

As I'm sure you know, our RoutePlanning programs must be able to infer the option to change lanes. This will be useful in two obvious cases (and perhaps other not so obvious ones).

-2- lane change to effect the most efficent solution in getting from current location to next checkpoint

item.title: RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?
item.author: jayg
item.description:
Posted by: jayg to Rules:RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?

BTW, stating that GPS error was THE reason sandstorm went off the road
in the first challenge is a dramatic oversimplification of
reality. It was one of several problems that added up to
failure at that point (perception bug + GPS error + preplanning error +
tracking error all at the same place = robot off road). The
damage repair the week before the race cut short the system testing at
a critical time that could have turned up any of these errors, but the
perception mechanism (sensors and software) was running as well as it
could be tested that day. This is documented exhaustively in
http://www.ri.cmu.edu/pubs/pub_4696.html (see pages 37 and 38
specifically) so no one has to guess or postulate about anything.

item.title: RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?
item.author: jayg
item.description:
Posted by: jayg to Rules:RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?

DARPA explicitly states that the GPS waypoints may vary wildly from the
actual road to force you to do visual sensing of the road
structure. Their sample RNDF even shows an example where the road
takes a 90 degree turn while the RDNF just cuts off the corner entirely.



This rule almost certainly is speaking to the lane marker type, not the
lane marker position. I think an example of the situation they
are trying to cover is this: The RNDF reports a double yellow
line as the lane marker. In reality, there is a break in the lane
marker for an irrelevant (to the race) intersection. DARPA wants
your vehicle to continue through that break acting as if there was a
double yellow line the whole way even though your sensors may tell you,
"hey, there is no double yellow line there."

item.title: RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?
item.author: DaveB
item.description:

item.title: New FAQ Responses
item.author: DaveB
item.description:

The E, in the second part of your first post you say, "My platform is a stock conversion. . ." It seems like the decision might depend on this. If the conversion is performed by a company that produces enough of them to truly call it stock, like, say, the old Shelby Mustangs, then you have a stock vehicle. Otherwise, probably not.

item.title: RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?
item.author: ptrep
item.description:
Posted by: ptrep to Rules:RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?

I think you would be surprised as to how accurate a good GPS/INS system coupled with a decent control algorithm can be. The vehicle was within about 7-8 cm of where we wanted it to be for pretty much the entire race.

item.title: RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?
item.author: DaveB
item.description:
Posted by: DaveB to Rules:RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?

I think DARPA and most teams fail to understand the challenges of steering this accurately with GPS and INS. The most conservative error numbers provided by manufacturers address accuracy to be expected 95% of the time, or 2 sigma. For the GPS numbers, that's also in good signal conditions. If you don't analyze this like an engineer, it sounds like "almost always", but you need to think in terms of how often the error will be outside that number, how far outside it might be, for how long, and how often that good signal will be unavailable. It's even harder to get a good feel for error buildup in the INS, but you can be sure it won't be good enough to keep a 7 ft wide vehicle between lines 12 feet apart for long.

This error is what ended Sandstorm's run in the first challenge (they had instrumentation to verify location by reference to the real world, but damaged that just before the challenge). The Urban Challenge should have worse GPS reception, among tall buildings, but it might not.

CONCLUSION: use sensors to determine the position of your vehicle, relative to the road, in order to correct GPS/INS position.

item.title: RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?
item.author: sapper023
item.description:
Posted by: sapper023 to Rules:RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?


I also agree , can someone put together a poll maybe ?
I personally think I can make something do this without GPS if landmarks are visibly available ( not good idea for in a sand storm ) . I think such a system that only uses visual would be rule compliant once it sees a route defined object ( stop sign for example ) .
Parking as " 5 stalls over from the left on row 3 as seen from entrance A " would be nice .
It seems DARPA wants GPS centric solutions and who can blame them as GPS requires less machine intelligence ( presumably more feasible in their eyes I suspect but I doubt the long term flexibility of consequently low intelligence systems ) and there is already an extensive infrastructure supporting GPS .


[Edited on 6/21/2006]

item.title: RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?
item.author: DividedBy0
item.description:
Posted by: DividedBy0 to Rules:RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?

It appears that what jayg and The E are saying is most plausible. DARPA is definitely not giving enough information in the RNDF to reconstruct the road and all its markings exactly, so visual systems will absolutely be necessary.

item.title: RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?
item.author: The E
item.description:
Posted by: The E to Rules:RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?

I had the same impression as jayg . The RNDF file will take precidence if the lane markers vary widely or do not match with the actual road indicators, i.e. road has a single white line and RNDF shows an island separator between lanes. I believe these are acceptable constraints. I don't believe the RNDF is there to steer you off road and have you running in the emergency lane or worse. Visual tracking of the lines should still be used to keep you in bounds when the RNDF and lane markers agree to a margin of error.

item.title: New FAQ Responses
item.author: The E
item.description:
Posted by: The E to Rules:New FAQ Responses

Actually DaveB, you are probably correct on this. However, this precludes any or most of us from performing any such activies on our challenge cars. Read: production automobiles. If the manufacturer is custom car fabricator I still believe the FAQ rule applies since it is not a factory line product. For new challange vehicles I believe the only exceptions are a car that has been on the road long enough to validate its safety or one that has undergone NHTSA/IIHS approved crash testing.

My conversation with DARPA was far more extensive than simply discussing my stock coversion. I believe there are details I should not post, but if anyone wants my read between the lines interpretation as given to me by an official send me an email ( antispam77.erw at glowriver.com )

I agree.. that is strange. If you wanna know what I think there should be no GPS involved in this competition at all, except maybe to give the coordinates of intersections that must be passed through. To have GPS supercede lane markings is simply rediculous.

item.author: www.TeamProdigies.com
item.description:
Posted by: www.TeamProdigies.com to Rules:New FAQ Responses

It is my opinion that it should be enough for DARPA if the vehicle is street-legal. If it's able to pass the state patrol tests and get a title, it can't be too bad. I doubt DARPA is going to change the rules on this one though.

item.title: RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?
item.author: DividedBy0
item.description:
Posted by: DividedBy0 to Rules:RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?

Thanks for the response, ptrep.

Looking at the OmniStar datasheets, it appears that really high accuracy can be obtained. And using INS for dead reckoning would account for intermittent GPS. So there goes my first point ;-)

As for the second point - is DARPA expecting us to completely ignore the lane markings on the ground? If the GPS points agree with the lane markings, then ignoring the lane markings and using GPS/INS would be fine. And if the GPS and lane markings disagree, then we are forced to use GPS. It appears to me that the physical lane markings are useless (except maybe for 3 point turns and such).

Thoughts?

Thomas

item.title: New FAQ Responses
item.author: wolfbob
item.description:
Posted by: wolfbob to Rules:New FAQ Responses

It would seem to me that DARPA's main concern is one of safety. For instance, in the event of a collision and a brake line is severed do you still have the capability to stop (all modern vehicles have dual redundancy in the braking system). If you muck with the fuel lines/tanks etc do you still have the safety inherent in typical motor vehicles to preclude fuel leakage, venting or spilling in any rational situation?

I think that if you do mess with the basic safety features, you must so indicate and show what you have done to preclude any hazard to anyone/anything in any event at least to the extent of damaging other vehicles/property or personnel. I don't think they would care if a simple fender-bender totally destroys YOUR vehicle as long as it doesn't hurt anything else.

Maybe something else to it, but I think this is the issue that brought forth the rule.

WBob.

item.title: New FAQ Responses
item.author: The E
item.description:
Posted by: The E to Rules:New FAQ Responses

After an exchange of emails with DARPA the verdict is stick with the terms in the FAQ. This overrules the statement of "stock chassis" in the PiP. What they're looking for is a mfg. stock vehicle with minimal modifications to its operating components.

Hope this helps anyone that had plans to do any major mechanical work to their challenge car.
