item.title: RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?
item.author: DividedBy0
item.description:
Posted by: DividedBy0 to Rules:RNDF Precedence Over Physical Lane Markings?

Hi All!

Just want to see what other people think of this rule in Section 1.7 of the Urban Challenge Rules (June 12):

DARPA’s intent is for the RNDF lane boundary descriptors to match the
physical lane markings on the ground. DARPA cannot ensure that this will be the case in
all areas, and as such the RNDF shall take precedence over the physical ground markings
in conflicting areas.


This rule troubles me for two reasons:

First, the RNDF is keyed to absolute survey (GPS) positions. The accuracy of GPS on the vehicles will vary and will probably never be less than 1 meter. I would think that staying in a narrow corridor defined by absolute GPS points would be practically impossible given meter-accuracy GPS. Even if the points given in the RNDF are 100% accurate, the vehicles will not have the ability to get survey-grade coordinates using differential GPS or WAAS GPS.

Second, what should the vehicle do if the GPS points (actual or measured) intersect a curb? Should the vehicle try to drive the curb to stay within the lines, or should it obey the physical lane markings?

It would seem to me that it would be better to perform fine-tuned lane following using visual systems on the vehicle that do not depend on external signals. What do other people think of this rule?

Thanks!
Thomas

item.title: New FAQ Responses
item.author: DaveB
item.description:
Posted by: DaveB to Rules:New FAQ Responses


Rules have evolved during vehicle development for the previous Grand Challenges, and there isn't much the teams can do except change their approach. You describe the modifications to your vehicle as little more that must be done on all entries to make them controllable by computer or microprocessor, but you'll need to give DARPA more detail than you've given here, if you want their blessing (and of course the final blessing doesn't come till your entry is accepted). I'm guessing they won't have any problem with it.

item.title: New FAQ Responses
item.author: The E
item.description:
Posted by: The E to Rules:New FAQ Responses


A stock chassis encompasses only the structural frame of the vehicle
and makes no mention to the inner workings such as the drive train,
steering, or fuel system.



My platform is a stock conversion to EV. This is certainly a change to
the drive train and consequently to the fuel system as well. It meets
the requirement of a "stock chassis" since the vehicle is based on a
production street legal mid-sized vehicle.



I had always taken the guidelines to mean a vehicle suitable for street
legal use and registrable in the state of California would qualify
under DARPA's guidelines.



I have sent a copy of this as an email to DARPA; not knowing the time
frame for their response I'm hoping to receieve some feedback from
others on this forum.

[Part 2 of 2]

item.title: New FAQ Responses
item.author: The E
item.description:
Posted by: The E to Rules:New FAQ Responses

I haven't posted until now since my proprosed vehicle platform fell relatively squarly into the guidelines proprosed in the PiP.

However, with the release of the FAQ on 6/15 an new question about vehicle requirements has arisen regarding FAQ #25.

25. Can a vehicle be modified and still be considered a “stock vehicle”?

The suspension, wheels, interior, and shell may be modified without
modifying the status of the vehicle as “stock.” All safety-critical
components must be retained from the original stock vehicle, including
the chassis, steering, fuel system, braking system, and drive train.



This differs from the statement "stock chassis" which is still present
in Urban_Challenge_PIP_Mod04_061506_Redlines .pdf. Where said vehicle
requirements state:



Vehicle must be built upon a full-size stock chassis or a full-size chassis with a

documented safety record. Vehicles smaller than a midsize commercial automobile such

as golf cart-type or all terrain vehicles (ATVs) do not meet this requirement.

[Part 1 of 2]

item.title: New FAQ Responses
item.author: The E
item.description:

My opening post was a bit convoluted so I'll summarize by asking:



Is it now against the rules to make modifications to the powertrain
aside from adding actuators and sensors? unless crash
testing or other "documented" means address the safety concern.

My first post indicates I am planning to replace the stock engine with an electric motor. This breaks the term "stock" from the FAQ; would I need a "documented safety record?"

item.title: *** Free Software ***
item.author: DaveB

If anyone wants a rough check of this viewer, or your own, the attached screen dump shows most of the route segments. It's from a quick import of the sample RNDF into a mapping program, Fugawi, by telling it to use tab delimiters and to ignore the first field. The location is near Falls Church, VA, west of Washington, DC, just east of I-495 (the Beltway).

Though Fugawi's maps are more accurate than most, it's apparent, in this view, that they're a few feet off.

item.title: Looking for a team - Image Processing
item.author: bworth
item.description:
Posted by: bworth to Teaming:Looking for a team - Image Processing

Most of the products I'm developing are for use in physical security applications. More recently I've been developing technologies for use in robot applications and include an object auto-tracking technology for pan/tilt mounted cameras, stereo vision disparity mapping, and object type recognition. The auto-tracking is the most mature technology though I need to add ego-motion estimation for use with mobile robots. I envisioned using that technology for modeling the kinematics of the motion fields around the vehicle. However, I have come to learn that there exists some new lidar technology that is capable of performing the same task, more expensive perhaps, but from a risk management standpoint the better option.

From a development standpoint, how are you folks situated? Were you able to get your vehicles automated last year, and what track are you considering persuing?

Thanks,

Bren

item.title: Where's the Open Source Grand Challenge Entry?
item.author: ezoltan
item.description:
Posted by: ezoltan to Technology:Where's the Open Source Grand Challenge Entry?

There's no need to get an organized team together. How about just creating some components that would be of use to anyone who is entering the challenge and making those components open source?

For example, DARPA has presented the RNDF and MDF file formats that every contestant must interpret in order to complete the challenge.

http://www.darpa.mil/grandchallenge/docs/ RNDF_MDF_Formats.pdf

How about a Java or C# class library providing a set of objects to represent the RNDF and MDF file contents? This would be a worthy open-source project. Anyone could create further open source projects using it as a basis.

Just a thought.

Erik Zoltan

item.title: Weight requirement
item.author: sapper023
item.description:
Posted by: sapper023 to Rules:Weight requirement

Buy 1 or 2 working used 1 ton vans preferably with working air conditioning and have a mechanic ready to help you test them before you buy them .
These gas guzzelers are often for sale cheap ( around $ 1K around here no AC ) because of the price of gas being so high shop for vehicals in depressed areas for wonderful deals look for somthing that has a big engine and no trailer hitch that the mechanic thinks will be easy to fix .
I really do not think you will be running up significant miles or wear on these contraptions to be expecting system failures .
Put a rack on each vehical that places your outside intrument packages at a standard hight if the 2 vehicals are not the same and then you will only be having to adjust software or firmware to switch between the 2 vehicals for the handeling characteristics ( accelleration , decelleration , stoping , turning ) .
There is lots of room in a 1 ton van for : a generator and batteries , extra fuel tank , computer racks , garbage can , refrigerator ( for jolt cola chips salsa beans and cheese ) , porta potty , cots .
The worts case you have somthing you can drive to save on hotel bills , best case you have a dog-house your wife can send you to after you win . To save money insure the vehicals as one driver only and not primary transportation ( recreational ) vehicals .

item.title: Inspiriation
item.author: LeenSTL
item.description:
Posted by: LeenSTL to Miscellaneous:Inspiriation

I've been working lately on a RoboMagellan bot which will have an embedded PC running Fedora Core 5, programmed in C++, any microcontrollers would probably be done in C or C++. It will follow GPS waypoints similar to a Grand Challenge vehicle. There are several types of RoboMagellan competitions being done around the country, of course they don't pay big bucks or anything.

For my teams 2005 GC vehicle, I did the code above the microcontroller level in C++ on Fedora Core 3. We had several microcontrollers which were programmed by other team members in C. Data collected from the microcontrollers and other input devices was collected and interpreted by my code.

While at the 2005 Grand Challenge I asked many of the teams about their choices of languages and OS platforms. I teach both C++ & Linux so I was pleased to see lots of those, and of course many teams also used C, C#, with OS choices mostly ranging from Linux to Mac (aka freeBSD) with a few Windows based systems. Some teams found that their vision drivers required Windows so they would use that for a vision server and Linux elsewhere.

One of the more impressive programming efforts was done by Team DAD which had all programming done in TI DSP assembler, no PC required!




[Edited on 6/1/2006]

item.title: Looking for a team in the Phoenix/Tuscon area
item.author: pgrayson@aimagic.org
item.description:
Posted by: pgrayson@aimagic.org to Teaming:Looking for a team in the Phoenix/Tuscon area

Sparky,

Which claims are you talking about?

That I worked for Ford Motor Company? Stop by my shop here in TC and I will be glad to show you my Ford Motor Company Executive ID card. They let me keep it as a souvineer when they disolved the steamship division.

Don't you remember? As many of the readers of this Forum may recall, when it became apparent that we had not raised enough money to finish our cars and transport them the 5,500 mile round trip to be in the 2005 race, I offered my teams services to the other teams. We farmed out team members to join other teams, sent parts, business contacts, etc. We shared whatever we had with the teams that signed up for it. Team members who remained here provided technical support to other teams. We provided advice on strategy, design, etc. Much of it was used in the 2005 race by the teams who had asked for it.

Yes, I think it is very important that people be aware of what they are getting into. Joining my team means that they will be working to make sure that the US Army gets the guidance system it needs as soon as possible - even if that means helping other teams. I don't think it would be fair to the Gold Star mothers to do it any other way. The quidance system we are working on does not belong to us, it belongs to the drivers who have been killed while waiting for it to be fielded.

Paul F. Grayson

item.title: Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge
item.author: Nelson Bridwell
item.description:
Posted by: Nelson Bridwell to Rules:Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge

Kevin:

I think that we all sympathize and understand your viewpoint.

However, although we all have a general idea what DARPA needs, none of us are in a position to dictate their detailed requirements.

And yes, although it is often quite superficial, good press is vital in any democracy. It was important in WWII, as General Patton discovered, and it is even more so today, where military operations are run in the context of daily popularity polls.

It is my personal belief that the 2004 DGC was almost killed off by that video clip of GhostRider falling over at the starting gate. That was what everyone remembered, and when DARPA goes before congress to request funding, impressions count.

Nelson

item.title: Weight requirement
item.author: Media Dude
item.description:
Posted by: Media Dude to Rules:Weight requirement

If life or fortune is being risked on an '85 Tahoe, you probably wouldn't have made it far anyway. The cost of the vehicle isn't half the problem the sensors will pose when cutting the check.

In the last GC, a custom vehicle could really make a difference through size or mobility. In an urban environment, building your own vehicle sounds like a waste of resources.

item.title: Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge
item.author: Sparky
item.description:
Posted by: Sparky to Rules:Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge

The whole drive-by-wire thing is trivial. You missed my point. What I said was don't double your work. A small ATV will take a different actuation system(physically) then a car. No need to get personal. Again, if you don't like the rules, don't participate. Have your own contest if you want.

item.title: Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge
item.author: Kevin
item.description:
Posted by: Kevin to Rules:Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge

If you think actuation of a control surface is a major problem in this competition, you don't understand the real problems. Actuation is trivial.
After the decision is made to stop, the type of vehicle to stop is a minor change. As I'm sure you've been told over and over, "Size doesn't matter".

item.title: Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge
item.author: Sparky
item.description:
Posted by: Sparky to Rules:Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge

To Kevin and those like him:

The competition is what it is. If you don't like it, don't participate. Review your physics. What vehicles on the road don't weigh at least one ton. This is the easy part. Convert your daily driver, or buy something else. All testing up to the site visit can occur with you sitting in the driver's seat. Finding a place to practice will always be an issue, but this is part of the competition. It isn't just about getting a technically viable vehicle, it's about what it takes to get to that point. And, unfortunately for those of us who are more technically minded, this means marketing and people skills. Start beating the bushes and making phone calls. You're bound to know someone, who knows someone, that can help. I would not recommend starting on a toy, then installing the systems on a full size vehicle. If you are truly working out of your garage, this will kill the project. You would have to do twice as much installation work, and vehicle dynamics are going to be different. Not to mention that you would more than likely need to use vastly different drive-by-wire actuation components.

The important thing about the rules is that they don't change drastically. The vehicle requirements should be stated up front, and held to.

item.title: Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge
item.author: Kevin
item.description:
Posted by: Kevin to Rules:Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge

Mr. Bridwell (and DARPA)
The expression of disappointment at arbitrary conditions which bars someone from a competition that could lead to his being able to make a true contributions to the country, and to the men who serve this country, have a slightly higher priority than good press. The original purpose of this competition, as I understood it, was to allow anyone with interest to try and solve problems that are now causing the loss of life to our service people overseas. This competition drew from a greater population than the "simple" competitions you advise as an alternative. To win at an SAE sponsored local event wouldn't lead to acceptance and action on the part of any governmental agency. It is an important competition; the heart of which is the creation of systems that can perceive real situations and take appropriate action based on that reality. When a motorcycle crashes within 5 yards of the start, although laughable for some, the lessons learned maybe the ones needed to accomplish the mission. The government has other means for getting "the big boys", large universities and businesses, involved. They don't need this competition as well. For Edison working in his garage, buying and running a one ton monster around the streets is not a possibility.

[Edited on 5/28/2006]

item.title: VIRGINIA CONFERENCE
item.author: arturomdn
item.description:
Posted by: arturomdn to Miscellaneous:VIRGINIA CONFERENCE

My interpretation of what was said is that the potential for potholes
should not dictate your choice of vehicles. There might be some
dirt roads, so road detection/road following needs to be flexible, not
just follow the curb or follow the yellow/white line, and there might
be a pothole here or there. The point of the challenge is not
off-road capability, the point of the challenge is not waypoint
following, it is traffic. For what it's worth, I believe Stanford
is using a VW Passat http://www.vw.com/passat/

item.title: Weight requirement
item.author: Kevin
item.description:
Posted by: Kevin to Rules:Weight requirement

I know you've heard this before but size doesn't matter. The winners of the last contest were full size vehicles when the condition was not mandatory. For those that have the resources or are taking Track A that's great.
Actuating controls is a trivial task compared to analyzing the conditions and calculating the required movement. Unless you think that a small vehicle has an advantage because it can move more between the lines without going out of the lane, I fail to see your point. Quite frankly if DARPA wants to limit it's contestants to schools and businesses, I'll just use my time somewhere else. With 25 years of programming experience and 10 years of control system and instrumentation development, I'm sure I can find something to do, for which I don't have to risk my life or fortune.

item.title: VIRGINIA CONFERENCE
item.author: DaveB
item.description:
Posted by: DaveB to Miscellaneous:VIRGINIA CONFERENCE

Not only do I think a Geo Metro could have finished the two off-road challenges, but I doubt it would even have been a disadvantage, but some of those who've actually traveled those courses might disagree. In addition, I'd bet the potholes in the next Challenge will be no worse than those around NYC, not that I'd want to drive into some of those. If a 4x4 was needed for this sort of driving, we’d all be driving them, and you aren't going to find out what obstacles the Challenge course will hold until that day comes, and I'll bet no one at DARPA will know until shortly before that day.

Any useful autonomous vehicle of the future will need to detect potholes and other pitfalls, so DARPA would probably much rather you provided a Geo with hole detection features than try to drive over them with a 6x6, or such. In fact, it might increase your chance of selection if you provided a hole or two in your on-site inspection course.

By the way, are you sure that Geo meets the as-delivered weight and size requirements? Hmmm, the specs for a '97 Metro make it look a bit light, but plenty long. Maybe you could find one with some heavy accessories. Then again a Prizm is plenty heavy, and a Tracker adds 4-wheel-drive to half-again more weight than required.

[Edited on 5/28/2006]

item.title: VIRGINIA CONFERENCE
item.author: Mark
item.description:
Posted by: Mark to Miscellaneous:VIRGINIA CONFERENCE

Darn, you're right! Darpa says it has to weigh under 2K lbs UNLADEN.



I was assuming the Geo Metro was 1900 lbs, and I would have at least 100 lbs of robotic equipment on it.



I wonder if DARPA realizes there are actually still some automobiles
out there that are under 2K lbs. I think they didn't know that
(as I didn't) and thought that 2000 lbs was a safe cutoff that would
seperate the automobiles from the golf carts.



If anyone's interested, try to ask DARPA if they'll allow a 90's Geo Metro

item.title: Weight requirement
item.author: DaveB
item.description:
Posted by: DaveB to Rules:Weight requirement

Well, it's a lot easier to keep a quad between the lines than a full-size vehicle. Also techniques you use to actuate vehicle controls are more likely to be universally useful if you're adapting a standard car. It's unfortunate if you have a place you could test that ATV and not an automobile, but maybe you could do development on that course, then move up to something like an '87 Chevy (or Jeep). When the time comes to test the full size version, you can surely find a country road or unused parking lot, but for the site visit it might improve your chances if you rent a lot somewhere, and lay down some lanes with white and yellow tape.

item.title: VIRGINIA CONFERENCE
item.author: Mark
item.description:
Posted by: Mark to Miscellaneous:VIRGINIA CONFERENCE

DARPA website makes it clear that the next challenge is not about
'offroading'. Yet there will be unpaved roads and potholes.



So are they hinting that I should still probably use a truck?
Because I sure would like to use a Geo Metro, if they aren't going to
hold it against me.



A Geo Metro will handle any rural unpaved road just fine, but I'm
wondering if the potholes will be radical enough that the vehicle could
get stuck in them.



Or maybe the 'potholes' will be so extremely radical that both the
GeoMetro AND a truck would both get stuck in the pothole, thus the
necessity of visually detecting them.



Maybe 'pothole' simply means the NYC potholes that I'm familiar with,
where it will cause a massive jolt to the vehicle, but will not cause
the vehicle to get stuck.



I really don't know. If anyone has any hints, let me know,
because it actually does have a pretty massive impact on vehicle choice.



Is anyone else planning to use an ordinary 2WD automobile?

item.title: Weight requirement
item.author: www.TeamProdigies.com
item.description:
Posted by: www.TeamProdigies.com to Rules:Weight requirement

Agreed.

item.title: Weight requirement
item.author: Kevin
item.description:
Posted by: Kevin to Rules:Weight requirement


I believe the weight and size requirement for the contest will eliminate anyone not connected with a company or university. Where can you test a one-ton vehicle? Control, instrumentation and detection systems don't rely on size or weight. A four wheeled cycle with the necessary systems should be able to compete. If the final mission includes the ability to transport items larger than the test vehicle is capable of carrying then the systems could be scaled up or move altogether. Requirements which eliminate a large proportion of those who competed last time, should be considered carefully. There are some of us out here in the cold who believe we have something to offer.

item.title: EMC
item.author: ptrep
item.description:
Posted by: ptrep to Miscellaneous:EMC

We were able to interface to steering/transmission/gas/throttle/brake/ turn signals/etc through voltage wires. There was no API to speak of. If we wanted to switch to Drive from Park, we would ground the Drive wire momentarily. Gas and steering were done by varying the voltage from ~.5 to ~4.5 volts.

All and all, it was easy to work with and was very reliable.

Paul
Team Gray

item.title: RNDF and MDF?
item.author: DaveB
item.description:
Posted by: DaveB to Miscellaneous:RNDF and MDF?

I agree with LeenSTL that a major reason the second Challenge was successful was the lengthy testing cycle, but I think DARPA deserves a lot of the credit for this. The schedule for that Challenge FORCED the teams to have working vehicles long before the NQE, giving them plenty of time to work out the bugs. The Urban Challenge is similar. You'll have to have something working by April 13, 2007, for the video, in order to get selected, and it better be working WELL by June 11, or you'll never get past the site visit. That gives you four and a half months to get it working RIGHT.

item.title: Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge
item.author: DaveB
item.description:
Posted by: DaveB to Rules:Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge

I doubt teams will be allowed near the course before the start. I've finally figured out a way to parse that sentence in Rules section 3.5, "Team activities to discover or exploit information about the course that is not openly available by pre-running or any other means may result in disqualification." so it means what I think they meant. Just add commas, "Team activities to discover or exploit information about the course that is not openly available, by pre-running or any other means, may result in disqualification." The original wording implies you CAN do pre-running, but that's probably not what they meant. Of course you could probably get away with working from existing aerial photos, etc, but it seems even THAT would be cheating, and as they said in the conference, that's not the challenge. The challenge will be the behavior with moving vehicles and other obstacles.

item.title: Kits for converting vehicles to computer control
item.author: LeenSTL
item.description:
Posted by: LeenSTL to Miscellaneous:Kits for converting vehicles to computer control

EMC did steering, throttle, brakes, and transmission for some teams in the GC 2005, I think they were charging about $30K, plus you had to get the vehicle to / from Louisiana. Apparently they did a good job on the Kat-5 vehicle!

For Roboteq's view of motor control in a full size vehicle go to roboteq.com and scan for something like "Controlling a full size vehicle", there was a motorhead show a few years back which made a giant RC vehicle using Roboteq gear. The ideas are the same for actuating the steering etc on a robot, of course instead of the Roboteq controller reacting to joystick signals you'd configure it to read serial commands from a PC or microcontroller. They work great, several teams used them in the GC vehicles.

Just out of curiosity, why do you ask about the horn? Since that is controlled by a relay, isn't a horn EZ to take over via a microcontroller?


[Edited on 5/23/2006]

item.title: Kits for converting vehicles to computer control
item.author: Mark Fiala
item.description:
Posted by: Mark Fiala to Miscellaneous:Kits for converting vehicles to computer control

Hello,

Does anyone have any good suggestions for where to get modules to install into a vehicle so that it can be controlled by computer? Gas, brakes, lights, horn, etc.

Ideally a kit that a mechanic can install. I assume some may exist for specific vehicles.

Another important feature would be one that can be easily turned on and off so that the vehicle could be controlled again by a human operator.

Perhaps something exists for quadrapelic drivers? (if they're allowed to drive at all anywhere).

Also, could someone post a description of how the control is typically done? I would guess that some cylinders could be added to the power steering, rather than some large contraption actually turning the steering wheel. The gas pedal could be controlled with some modification to the cruise control mechanism. Just some guesses from a non-mechanic person.

Apologies if this is quite a "newbie" question, I've trolled a little bit on this site and only found one company offering conversion of vehicles.
Mark

item.title: VIDEOption
item.author: Mark Fiala
item.description:
Posted by: Mark Fiala to Vendor/Suppliers:VIDEOption

Hello, I just sent a private message but then figured others might want to see this conversation in case they were interested in your services.

Can you give estimates of prices to get a vehicle converted to automatic control? Likely this is only possible for vehicle models that you have experience with.

This would lead to the question of what vehicles you suggest, ones that are more amenable to adding controls.

Also, with your modifications, is it possible to have a simple way to deactivate the computer control so that the vehicle can be driven normally again?

Finally, any possibilities to buy subsystems from you, for teams like mine with a low budget?

Thanks,
Mark

item.title: RNDF and MDF?
item.author: LeenSTL
item.description:
Posted by: LeenSTL to Miscellaneous:RNDF and MDF?

Bob H, I think that Car TV mentions that Dexter was doing very well, actually winning up to the point where they went out, in their piece on the GC event. The Nova piece focuses on Team Dad among others, they are the ones that lost their innovative spinning laser array. They have all-around coverage with that unit, perfect for the UC!

There were many good teams that on another day might have won. Clearly the thing that set the better teams apart was the massive amount of testing they did. Take a look at any of the better teams and you'll find that they didn't just start testing right before the NQE, they spent much of the summer or even longer working out the kinks. That is probably one of the reasons why the Gray Team was so good, they actually rented a quarry, built their own test course and drove in it right from the beginning.

As far as the Red Team's performance in the GC 2005, if they had reversed the performance profiles for the vehicles and made Sandstorm the more aggressive of the two then they probably would have taken first and fourth places, possibly letting Kat-5 finish ahead of H1ghlander. I'm sure if they had any inkling of the loss of power problems in H1ghlander they would have done something different.

item.title: RNDF and MDF?
item.author: sapper023
item.description:
Posted by: sapper023 to Miscellaneous:RNDF and MDF?


While delighted with the successes of sincere competitors who did do a noble effort I was troubled by those who did do things like fly overs and other prior mapping methods as the latter were polluting good science with going for the money halfway measures that did not result in substantive technological innovation . While fly overs or some sort of mapping and use of emissive devices may be helpful in research dependence on such would be shameful to present as anything other than a intermediate stop gap measure for controlled applications .
The best solutions will be without dependence on emissive devices and capable of operation where needed even if it is on mars for example or with some wrong information .
Those are good people who did the good work of making flexible systems capable of going from point A to point B well .
It is clear to me that there are still people trying to just go for the money and not just make something that can work despite any rule changes that may come .
My condolences to those sincere individuals who found themselves in teams which had members of no scientific integrity in control .
It is my hope that DARPA holds a hard line of rules that will prevent a non usefull result for they seem to be asking for something that will be useful and we all have learned from the past what should be asked for .

item.description:

So will this mean that homemade vehicles aren't allowed??!!!?

item.title: Taxicab Algorithm
item.author: Nibor
item.description:
Posted by: Nibor to Miscellaneous:Taxicab Algorithm

Wolfbob, the short version is probing and inching in until max cabs in min space. Interesting math exercise but doesn't go anywhere in NY either.

I can see this with a bot starting into a turn and then breaking, paused, or just becoming senile resulting in a pileup. A real good one would be a string of bots starting up a blocked lane. My vivid imagination sees the advantage of a 30,000 lb monster truck. Wonder if driving around on top of bots counts as a collision?

WBob

item.title: RNDF and MDF?
item.author: Bob H
item.description:
Posted by: Bob H to Miscellaneous:RNDF and MDF?

It seems as if a lot of effort is going in to make sure that the RED Teams approach to this race is not repeated, but I have not seen anyone actually mention their name. Am I missing some good info? Clearly, Red's 2 Teams used every legal angle available to them including gaming the system, which is probably what this is all about. DARPA is clearly putting its experience to work on GC3, and specifying more clearly what it wants to see. I don't see enough people giving credit to the 3 to 5 teams that did not finish last year, but were VERY close if not for...flat tire, loose strap, etc.. and I just read (on the Red Team's web site) that one of Red Teams trucks finished within 2 minutes of the time it was told to. So that if Red W. had said finish in 5 hours, the thing might have done just that.

item.title: USB 2.0 Flash Drive
item.author: DaveB
item.description:
Posted by: DaveB to Miscellaneous:USB 2.0 Flash Drive

Centrex, I don't know, but I'll bet a cookie the flash drive will be returned to DARPA before the start, so they can load the next mission while the vehicle does its thing. Even if you could keep it, I recommend you put it onto your own hard or flash drive, because you don't know how fast DARPA's memory will be. USB 2.0 can be VERY fast (it think my 2 gig drive is faster than my hard drive, but haven't tested it), but if you have slow flash memory, it's a moot point. If you read the specs, the speeds are orders of magnitude different.

item.title: Greater Autonomy
item.author: DaveB
item.description:
Posted by: DaveB to Rules:Greater Autonomy

wolfbob, you say, "you are also given a number of missions", and "Once you have completed a mission. . .". I don't believe you get the 2nd mission till you complete the 1st, and so on, nor to I think you start the 2nd mission at a different location, and I'm certain the time in the pits counts against your Challenge time.

There ARE up to 20 vehicles flailing around the circuit at the same time, plus DARPA said they'll add some of their own, and not only do you lose if some jerk takes you out, but you can't use the backup car you may have brought along, but you CAN use it to switch before the final event as long as it uses the same software, and you CAN canabalize it for parts. DARPA made it clear, in their talk, that there will be one very busy intersection, as LeenSTL described.

They said the conference materials will be available online, hopefully including the video we watched live.

item.title: RNDF and MDF?
item.author: LeenSTL
item.description:
Posted by: LeenSTL to Miscellaneous:RNDF and MDF?

Another effect of using an undisclosed location is the inability of deep-pocket teams to get satellite or lidar fly-overs and cartography drive-overs as was done in GC 2004 & 2005.

item.title: RNDF and MDF?
item.author: arturomdn
item.description:
Posted by: arturomdn to Miscellaneous:RNDF and MDF?

I think what LeenSTL is referring to was a comment by DARPA that the
roads that will be used for the event are probably not to be found in
an existing public GIS database. However, they went on to say
that they will release an aerial picture of the area, and release a
version of the RNDF in advance because this event is not "about the
waypoints" it is about traffic interaction and avoiding
collisions. We can study the RNDF all we want, what matters is
detecting and detail tracking of vehicles, especially at intersections
to determine right of way. They said the site visit will be very,
very tough, as will the NQE where the vehicle might be tested merging
into traffic twenty times. Dangerous behavior will not be
tolerated. Overly cautious behavior will not be tolerated.
Basically, the robot should assess situations and react in a timely
manner, should merge into traffic and "tuck in" while keeping a prudent
but not excessive distance (8 meters). That is my understanding,
correct me if I'm wrong.

I haven't seen much information about the standard USB 2.0 flash drive in the provided documentation from DARPA.

Does anyone know if the flash drive will be removed once the MDF and RNDF have been loaded at the beginning of each mission (at the start chute), or if it will remain connected throughout the mission, or the entire challenge.

item.title: Greater Autonomy
item.author: LeenSTL
item.description:
Posted by: LeenSTL to Rules:Greater Autonomy

At the conference the idea was given that the sample file size times a small number would be about the size of the eventual RNDF. Picture four of the areas defined in the sample file, each radiating out from a central traffic circle, this might be something like the eventual RNDF. Since all bots would be active on similar but different missions, there would be a constant flow of bot traffic through the traffic circle, at intersections, etc, plus there would be some additonal human traffic interjected by DARPA, along with blockages which could come and go.

The more I hear, the more I think this should be called the Grander Challenge!

item.author: DaveB
item.description:
Posted by: DaveB to Miscellaneous:RNDF and MDF?

LeenSTL, the draft rules are now posted, and Section 6.4.1 includes, "The UFE RNDF will be provided to teams at least 24 hours in advance of the start." Conclusion: there will only be one RNDF for one event, and it'll be available well ahead of time.

item.title: Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge
item.author: DaveB
item.description:
Posted by: DaveB to Rules:Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge

Nibor, I'm not sure whether you want to know where DARPA got the idea to require full-size vehicles, or where the quote came from. If it's the latter, see the first bullet in Section 2.2 of the PIP (Proposer Information Pamphlet for Track A). If it's the former, maybe they're hoping for designs that can readily be backfit into a full size vehicle, and trying to prevent teams from wasting resources designing something that already exists. Maybe they also think an ATV would have an unfair advantage staying within the lanes in city traffic, and/or be harder for the others to "see".

I suspect any "dune buggy" that made the trials last year would be considered as meeting the "proven safety record", if it meets the 72 inch, 2000 lb, criteria (or were modified to meet them), but suggest the team ask DARPA before investing much effort in that vehicle.

item.title: Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge

We happen to have a "surplus" vehicle specifically designed and built for GC06 that can be modified to meet Urban07 draft rules. I feel an e-mail to DARPA coming on.

item.author: DaveB
item.description:
Posted by: DaveB to Rules:Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge



Seems like DARPA needs to revise the last paragraph of Rules section 3.5, which includes this sentence, "Team activities to discover or exploit information about the course that is not openly available by pre-running or any other means may result in disqualification." They must have intended the "or by any other means" to mean other activities to discover information about the course are prohibited, but I can't parse the sentence to get that meaning. That phrase should be deleted.

item.title: RNDF and MDF?
item.author: LeenSTL
item.description:
Posted by: LeenSTL to Miscellaneous:RNDF and MDF?

The only definite thing I can see is that the RNDF has to be available before the MDF can be processed, because the MDF is tied to a specfic RNDF.

Perhaps at a competition there will be multiple RNDFs available, and the bot has to choose the one that is specified in the MDF that gets actually loaded in. That gives five minutes to activate the specific RNDF and have it start feeding info to process the MDF.

item.title: Greater Autonomy
item.author: wolfbob
item.description:
Posted by: wolfbob to Rules:Greater Autonomy

I don't quite get it.....

I think that you are given a chunk of city, say a mile square with roads, checkpoints, stop signs, parking lots etc all defined in GPS map coordinates. You are also give a number of missions that are checkpoints in an order and speeds designed to begin and end at the city boundry. Once you have completed a mission, you vehicle is turned back over to the team and you can put air in the tires and wash the windshield and drive it to the entry point for the next mission. This process continues for 60 miles or 6 hours.

Are there some 20-40 vehicles all flailing around inside of this "city" at the same time and are they going to be the moving targets you are to avoid running into? Who wins when some defective runs into your perfect vehicle and you are retired? beginning to look like Terramax is a good idea. (think battlebots).

I thot sommore and with 30 ft roads spaced at 100ft you would have around 100 miles bidirectional roads in my mile square grid. With 40 cars evenly spread out over 200 miles there would be 10 cars going in each of 4 directions. The 10 coming at you are spread over 50 roads so they are not a big deal. The 20 going across your direction are distributed over 2500 intersections so you would never see them...etc...not an issue. just how big is this city going to be???

item.title: Applanix - Commercial Off The Shelf INS/GPS Navigation For Autonomous Vehicles
item.author: Applanix
item.description:
Posted by: Applanix to Vendor/Suppliers:Applanix - Commercial Off The Shelf INS/GPS Navigation For Autonomous Vehicles

POS LV is a compact, fully integrated, turnkey position and orientation system, utilizing integrated inertial technology to generate stable, reliable and repeatable positioning solutions for land-based autonomous vehicle applications. Designed to operate under the most difficult GPS conditions found in urban and suburban environments, POS LV enables accurate positioning for autonomous vehicles and vehicle dynamics.



Generates continuous, accurate, position and orientation information under the most difficult GPS conditions
Produces precise, high-rate, low-latency, real-time data
Allows quick operational capability, with installation, calibration and training completed in as little as three days
Includes an automatic redundant data logging capability
Uses the latest survey-grade GPS technology for improved positioning performance

For more information about POS LV, contact Louis Nastro at:
lnastro@applanix.com
(905) 709-4600 x 482

For detailed product information and technical / white papers please visit:

item.title: Sample RNDF Map Question
item.author: Patriot Robots
item.description:
Posted by: Patriot Robots to Miscellaneous:Sample RNDF Map Question

Greetings,

I've been studying the RNDF example map and was wondering if anybody else had this question about line segment #2: Waypoint 2.1.2 is checkpoint 7. Waypoint 2.1.3 is around the corner of an intersection. I don't see any GPS data for that intersection--which is fine. No stop sign. Fine. We'll just have to determine that there IS an intersection and turn right. Here's where my question starts:

Assuming that Waypoint 2.1.3 is blocked and my vehicle cannot proceed, the robot will have to make a U-turn, go back to the intersection, and then what, proceed north on that undocumented road in the map until the robot reacquires the path toward waypoint 2.1.5 skipping 2.1.3 and 2.1.4? Furthermore, according to the RNDF, the segment is defined as one-way. Does this suggest we will never have an obstruction that will force us to calculate an alternate path within a one-way road?

--Ray

item.author: pgrayson@aimagic.org
item.description:
Posted by: pgrayson@aimagic.org to Teaming:Looking for Team in WA State

I worked for Ford's steamship division and have a team here in Traverse City, MI. I have worked at the Navy's Mobile-Robotics Laboartory http://www.nosc.mil/robots and have worked on the DARPA Grand Challenge for nearly five years now. Robots I have worked on are already in the field with US troops. If you want to get involved - joining my team is a very good way.

We are preparing three vehicles for the Urban Driving Challenge: AV ANDREA MORGAN - VW dune buggy; AV SYDNEY BRISTOW eight wheel drive four wheel steer US Army truck made by TATRA All Terrain Vehicles Inc; AV WENDY DARLING 2.5T US Army Cargo Truck.

We have a team of fundraising people working for us who have signed up Gates Rubber, TATRA All Terrain Vehicles Inc., National Instruments, and NeuroDimensions and others sponsors.

We have a contract to produce guidance systems for trucks as an aftermarket product.

Come up to TC for a shop visit, drive the eight wheel drive four wheel steer TATRA truck around in our sand lot and see our seven bay workshop.

My question has been (and this will probably be answered at the conference), "It is clear that the MDF is only given 5 minutes before the attempt, But when is the RNDF given?" In my opinion it should be at the same time, but they may give it out sooner. If they do give it out earlier, then teams could possibly "scope out" the course in advance.

item.title: Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge
item.author: www.TeamProdigies.com
item.description:

If any of you who are going to the competitor's conference read this and happen to agree with me on these points, I urge you to bring the issues up at the conference!

item.title: Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge
item.author: www.TeamProdigies.com
item.description:
Posted by: www.TeamProdigies.com to Rules:Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge

Hmm yeah. I don't like any of those. Except the USB flash drive. I approve of that. As for the vehicle requirements, however, I am currently building myself an electric car just to drive between home, my highschool, and the local community college. I was planning on using this vehicle as my Urban Challenge entry chassis, but I was also planning on building it to be a two-seater car considerably smaller than a mid-size commercial automobile. Maybe somewhere around the size of an MG Midget. If you've seen one of those cars you know what I'm talking about.

Recognition of traffic lights and stop signs through the use of sensors is not only child's play in comparison to the grand scheme of this competition, but in my opinion it should most certainly be included in the rules. If the vehicles are supposed to obey traffic laws, then traffic-light and stop-sign recognition should certainly be "withinin the scope of this program". DARPA is once again pointing the rules towards dead-reckoning, GPS following vehicles not truly capable of responding to their environment in practical situations.

item.title: Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge
item.author: Nelson Bridwell
item.description:
Posted by: Nelson Bridwell to Rules:Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge

I can entirely sympathize with your viewpoint.

However, because DARPA is organizing, paying for, and putting their name on this competition, they also have the right to ask for what they want and need, rather than what you would like to provide. One practical consideration is that they need good press, and it doesn't take a genius to realize that they would be the subject of laughter and ridicule if a team decided to submit an autonomous skateboard, even if it could pass the other technical requirements.

But there is absolutely no reason why you can't organize a simple (non-DARPA) event that is open to smaller vehicles. That would give you an opportunity to prove your assertions. If you keep it simple and eliminate all the non-vital overhead and expenses, you will be able to pull it off. There are lots of previous DARPA teams with small vehicles that would make idea candidates.

I would check to see if you could affiliate it with the SAE - The Society of Automotive Engineers: www.sae.org They are very into automotive technology and quite keen to promote student interest.

Also, you might want to look into the annual Intelligent Ground Vehicle Competition, which is geared to teams of engineering students from universities: www.igvc.org/deploy/

Very best of luck!



[Edited on 5/12/2006]

item.title: RNDF and MDF?
item.author: DaveB
item.description:
Posted by: DaveB to Miscellaneous:RNDF and MDF?


Since the RNDF will provide "GPS coordinates of the stop signs", lane width, and lane markings, my first guess is that it will include a detailed set of waypoints (with a waypoint at each segment of each radiused corner, at each change of lane width or lane marking, and at each intersection), plus a separate leg info section providing the lane marking and width and stopsign info in each direction between all connected waypoints. My second guess is that it will contain only a single section, providing the same leg info, plus coordinats of each end of the leg, leaving it up to your system to figure out where the roads connect by matching waypoint coordinates. Since stop sign info will be in GPS coordinates, I'll bet that all waypoint info will be in Lat/lon format, rather than, say, UTM, or State Coordinates.

By the way, LeenStl, your recollection of the load time for the MDF is off. The PIP, section 2.3, first bullet, states, "The vehicle will have 5 minutes to process a mission description before attempting the course." (it's also in the first bullet of Article III)

item.title: Greater Autonomy
item.author: Nelson Bridwell
item.description:
Posted by: Nelson Bridwell to Rules:Greater Autonomy

"To complete the requirements for the Urban Challenge, each vehicle will complete multiple missions over a defined route network. The route network definition specifies accessible roads and all areas in which the vehicle may travel. A mission is a series of checkpoint locations that must be passed over sequentially by the vehicle. The path between checkpoints is not specified."

"DARPA will provide the Route Network Definition File (RNDF) that includes all accessible road segments and provides information such as waypoints, stop sign locations, lane widths, checkpoint locations, and parking spot locations. The route network has no implied start or end points. Road blockages will not be indicated in the RNDF."

"DARPA will also provide a Mission Data File (MDF) containing the checkpoints that must be reached and maximum and minimum speed limits for the road segments. MDFs will be provided by DARPA for all Urban Challenge test events."

So it sounds like the vehicles will be demonstrating greater autonomy and should be capable of greater flexibility in carrying out missions.

[Edited on 5/11/2006]

item.title: Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge
item.author: Nelson Bridwell
item.description:
Posted by: Nelson Bridwell to Rules:Some interesting points about the 2007 Urban Challenge

"Vehicle must be built upon a full-size stock chassis or have a documented safety record. Vehicles smaller than a midsize commercial automobile do not meet this requirement. Golf cart-type or all terrain vehicles (ATVs) do not meet this requirement."
No more GhostRiders, CyberRiders, or golf carts!

"Vehicle must be capable of loading a mission description file via a standard USB 2.0 flash drive." "The vehicle will have 5 minutes to process a mission description before attempting the course."
No more marathon pre-race micromanagement in the planning trailer by a herd of grad students!

"The following behaviors or capabilities are outside the scope of this program: Recognition of external traffic signals such as traffic lights and stop signs through the use of sensors. The Urban Challenge route network definition file will include information such as stop sign locations, nominal lane width, lane markings, and parking spot locations."
It might be possible to accomplish with minimal (if any) vision processing.

item.title: A harder course.
item.author: John Nagle
item.description:
Posted by: John Nagle to Technology:A harder course.

The SICK LMS is a huge pain to interface correctly, but once you understand its wierd I/O limitations, it's straightforward enough. Once we figured out how to operate it properly, we were consistently able to reset it from faulted states. (We also did have a solid state power relay so we could power-cycle it if necessary, with appropriate software support, but that turned out to be unnecessary).

If you don't want a "dazzle" or "dirt" shutdown, you can set Availability Mode 3. Or just reset the thing.

The main issue in talking to the thing at 500,000 baud is that its little 8-bit microprocessor can't actually receive that fast. You have to provide a specified time delay between each byte sent to the device. This is documented in the SICK manual, but it's not emphasized.

We had the thing connected to a Sealevel Ethernet to serial converter good for up to 1mb/s or so, which handled the input side nicely.

SICK really needs to put a more modern controller in that thing. The present electronics are a decade old.

But you're not going to win the Urban Challenge with SICK units. It's time to move up.

item.title: A harder course.
item.author: Nelson Bridwell
item.description:
Posted by: Nelson Bridwell to Technology:A harder course.

The DARPA Grand Challenge is one of the VERY FEW competitions that has the potential to actually push the technological envelope and has resulted in some long-overdue technical progress in this field. Almost all other "ROBOT" competitions have almost nothing to do with robotics and are instead pep rallys for elementary or high school students.

As such, I hope that it will never be "dumbed down" (if you will please excuse the poor choice of words). I am entirely in favor of encouraging student interest in engineering and the sciences, particularly in the USA. But we also need competions for experienced engineers to push the state of the art. We have all been sitting around for far too many decades, wating for real robots to finally make an appearance.

item.title: How to do the Urban Challenge
item.author: John Nagle
item.description:
Posted by: John Nagle to Technology:How to do the Urban Challenge

Once you have a decent world model, making driving decisions will be interesting. It's going to take more than the pure reactive models many teams used last time. Behavior amidst human traffic will require some development work, although much of that can be done in simulation. That's going to be fun to work on.

Then you'll need substantial test space, and you'll probably dent some vehicles trying to get traffic behavior right.

Still, I think DARPA set the bar to about the right height this time. Someone may win the first time, and someone will win the second time.

John Nagle
Team Overbot (2002-2005)


[Edited on 5/3/2006]

item.title: How to do the Urban Challenge
item.author: John Nagle
item.description:
Posted by: John Nagle to Technology:How to do the Urban Challenge

Sensing options that could work include vision (more on this later), multibeam LIDAR systems like Team DAD had last year, and flash LIDAR systems. I'd look at flash LIDARs; we saw a good one last year, but couldn't use it because it was DoD-funded and not available by the cutoff date for that. This time, there's no problem. Also, I expect Team DAD will be back. Their 60-beam LIDAR was a nice little gadget, collecting enough data for this year, but not rugged enough. They'll fix that.

On the vision front, cameras bring in enough data, but of course, object extraction from cameras is hard. That's the cutting-edtge R&D problem this time. Millimeter radar might also be useful, especially since you can scan electronically, cars are good targets, and you get range rate. Last time, radar wasn't all that useful because it's a poor terrain sensor, but this time, it will probably play a bigger role. Using a good radar as the primary sensor for other moving vehicles may be the easiest way to approach the problem, and I'm sure it will be tried.

The world model needs to encompass fixed and moving obstacles. And some of the fixed obstacles might change to moving ones, as a vehicle starts to move. That's an area of research that hasn't received enough attention.

item.title: A harder course.
item.author: Sparky
item.description:
Posted by: Sparky to Technology:A harder course.

Yes, there is an "availability" bit that can be changed in the configuration that will ignore the "dazzle" issue. Many teams didn't know about this until the NQE. You could look at the failure log to see what happened with the unit. One thing that does not get recorded is a failure due to high temperature. This was another reason for failure of some units. They worked fine after they cooled down, though.

item.title: How to do the Urban Challenge
item.author: John Nagle
item.description:
Posted by: John Nagle to Technology:How to do the Urban Challenge

This looks difficult, but possible.

First, I'm assuming that everyone reading this understands how GC entries from last time around worked. If you don't, go read the tech papers.

Things are simpler than they were two years ago. You can buy many of the key components, including drive-by-wire vehicle controls and GPS/INS/magnetic compass/gycrocompass/odometer integration. Three years ago, you couldn't do that, which tied up much development time for the first teams. Now, you just throw money at the problem. About $100K gets you through that part. Get the good fibre optic gyro option; you'll lose GPS in urban environments all the time.

On the sensing side, we have some new challenges. Approaches based on line scanners (like the SICK units) probably aren't going to be enough this time. Approaches based on those mostly assume a static world. This time, vehicles will need to be able to handle both fixed and moving obstacles. The moving obstacles will have to be identified and their behavior modelled and predicted. Note the requirement of being able to merge into traffic and behave properly at intersections. That's the big challenge.

item.title: Track A
item.author: DaveB
item.description:
Posted by: DaveB to Rules:Track A

ptrep, sorry I'm not a lawyer, but as an engineer retired from a company working on DARPA and other military related jobs, my comments may help:

1. Don't expect a lawyer to sort it out. It's the engineers and administrators who must do it. Consult alawyer only for things you can't understand, and to review your submissions when complete. It's like doing taxes for the first time, read everything a couple times, then start plugging away and the questions will get answered as you go.

2. If you're not a company or school with a significant reputation, made at least the NQE last year, or already have a vehicle that can drive itself in town, it's unlikely you'll be selected for Track A. You've got to be able to convince DARPA that you CAN and WILL produce a vehicle that can complete the courses. The teams that finished the Grand Challenge have a good chance of selection. Everyone else has a long way to go, but the good news is you can always revert to Track B.

3. Don't be too upset by those clauses that require you to give up your technology. Federal law prohibits the government from requiring you to give them your existing technology in order to get a contract, and the PIP is clear on this. However, to keep your existing technology proprietary, you're going to have to declare, in your bid, exactly what you're keeping proprietary.

item.title: Problem which ended your vehicles chance at NQE?
item.author: LeenSTL
item.description:
Posted by: LeenSTL to Miscellaneous:Problem which ended your vehicles chance at NQE?

There has been enough time since the NQE to talk about this now (I hope). I'm sure that emotions were high at the time since not qualifyng at the NQE must have been a kick in the rear. What conclusions have you come to about your 2005 team vehicle and why it could not qualify at NQE, and what will be needed to make it competitive in the Urban Challenge?

This time around, just getting to the NQE at least earns your team some bucks (for track B teams that is), qualifying earns more also. This helps to offset the costs of developing these hi-tech bots.

item.title: A harder course.
item.author: LeenSTL
item.description:
Posted by: LeenSTL to Technology:A harder course.

Don't give up yet! Isn't there some reset code that some of the teams used to reset their Sick Laser scanners when a reset was needed? I seem to remember reading about that in one of the teams blogs, maybe Cyberrider? They didn't know about it until after they discovered the problem at NQE.

I met one of the guys from your team on Sunday morning at the closing ceremony, I think he was able to get an airplane ride over the course on Saturday! Now that would have been cool, did he get any good video?

Also, the bot won't have to sense stop lights, right? Besides, those are easy: green go, red stop, yellow speed up.


[Edited on 5/3/2006]

item.title: Looking for Team in WA State
item.author: LeenSTL
item.description:
Posted by: LeenSTL to Teaming:Looking for Team in WA State

Take a look at the teams that registered for GC2005 and see if any are in your area. I seem to recall there was a team that made it to the semi-finals, Team Wave perhaps?

At any rate, you'll find that teams begin forming after the conference, it's a bit early yet since the announcement just came out yesterday. You will probably see new teams forming for this challenge, although conventional wisdom says that teams with pre-existing vehicles have a huge lead. If that were true then CMU would have won GC2005.

item.title: Where's the Open Source Grand Challenge Entry?
item.author: danda
item.description:
Posted by: danda to Teaming:Where's the Open Source Grand Challenge Entry?

Cross posting this here, from the technology section.

----

Hi, my name is Dan Libby.

I would like to solicit feedback on the idea of creating an open source project to build re-usable components for automated cars, that could be shared between teams.

Likely it has already been discussed, but hey -- I'm new here, so maybe you'll indulge me and tell me why it is a crazy idea, won't work, or is against the rules, or whatever. Or just *maybe* you'll volunteer to help out.

Anyway, please read my preliminary post on the topic here:

http://dandaddl.livejournal.com/2006/05/0 2/

Regards,

Dan

[Edited on 5/3/2006]

item.title: Where's the Open Source Grand Challenge Entry?
item.author: danda
item.description:
Posted by: danda to Technology:Where's the Open Source Grand Challenge Entry?

Thanks for the info Dave. I'll contact Ivar and see what happened.

It would be a pity if no one wants to cooperate. Clearly there are areas of commonality that could be shared between teams, yet still leaving lots of room for proprietary algorithm additions and tweaks, for that winning edge.

I think this is too important to keep all the code locked away. If even just one team with a plausible entry in last year's event would be willing to donate some (or all) of their code, that would be a great seed for a FOSS project.

One solution might be a 32,0000 pound truck and 1 line of code: if (TrafficClear) MERGE else MERGE :))) next problem please!

item.title: A harder course.
item.author: mike
item.description:
Posted by: mike to Technology:A harder course.

This third year of the Darpa Challenge is going to be tough[Image Removed]. I am on the Palos Verdes high school Road Warriors Team. We entered the challenge twice and now our equipment may not be able handle sensing parked cars, stop lights, and pedestrians. Our car is called the Doom Buggy and in the last challenge the sun blinded the lasers that we had and we crashed into a "Rent a Wreck" car that was possitioned outside the tunnel. If our car can not see a big ford mustang how will it be able to see people and traffic cones. I hope the course is not very hard (Even thought it will be) because or car needs more lasers and we will give it our best. I hope we get to try the course.

item.title: RoboRealm - Free Robotic Machine Vision Software
item.author: RoboRealm
item.description:
Posted by: RoboRealm to Vendor/Suppliers:RoboRealm - Free Robotic Machine Vision Software

RoboRealm provides you with an interactive and experimentation vision
system to investigate the very complex world of image analysis and
image processing. Through an easy to use analysis pipeline you can add
image processing filters to translate an image into robotic movements,
computer actions, or just plain fun! RoboRealm is free to download!

Image and/or video processing can be technically difficult. Robots
are continuously moving towards high powered PC based systems that are
capable of supporting complex image processing functions. Sometimes you
just need a testbed of current image processing applications to test
potential ideas that you want your robot or computer+camera application
to perform. We've compiled several image processing functions into a
freely available windows based application that you can use with your
computer's webcam. You can use it to test out your vision ideas and see
what may be possible or not.

Free Robotic Machine Vision Software

item.title: Preliminary rules = CDL
item.author: pgrayson@chartermi.net
item.description:
Posted by: pgrayson@chartermi.net to Rules:Preliminary rules = CDL

My team is going on its fifth year now of working to promote the race, assist other teams, and outfit three vehicles of our own.
We are looking at having our driving system qualify for a CDL with air brakes endorsement.
Our newest sponsor TATRA All Terrain Trucks hope to make our system an after market option for thier line of trucks.
If you are looking for a team to join please consider joining my all-volunteer team. We could use your help.

Please note that my contact information has changed since the last race. We are now in a bigger workshop on the other side of town and my internet service provider has changed my e-mail address.

Roboteq, Inc
Cosma Pabouctsidis
Phoenix, Arizona
www.roboteq.com


Roboteq makes a dual channel, high power DC motor controller designed for mobile robotics application. The controller can be interfaced in a variety of ways, including analog, pulse, or RS232. It can operate in speed and position mode. In the position mode, using an external potentiometer and a geared motor, it can be used to create extremely powerful servos capable of driving the steering of large and heavy vehicle, as well as brakes, throttle and other controls. Detailed product information, including the 130 pages manual is available for download from our web site.

item.title: PMDTechnologies GmbH
item.author: Moderator
item.description:
Posted by: Moderator to Vendor/Suppliers:PMDTechnologies GmbH

PMDTechnologies GmbH
Bianca Hagebeuker
57076 Siegen, Germany
www.PMDTec.com


Only by capturing and processing the complete 3D scene an independent orientation can be observed or a prediction of the behaviour of a dynamic system be made. PMD Technologies has invented a new approach to realize simple, precise, and low-cost 3D-sensor-systems. This new and revolutionary generation of smart-pixel sensors delivers 3D depth maps directly, in real time. The PMD-Technology (Photonic Mixer Device) allows every pixel in a smart imager to measure both the distance as well as the grey scale value of a projected point, even under strong ambient light conditions. All of this is realized in standard CMOS process. No other sensors are suited to such a versatile range of applications. In particular for autonomous vehicles the PMD-Technology plays a key role: small and robust cameras are in the position to capture the third dimension of the complete 3D environment.

item.title: Xilinx
item.author: Moderator
item.description:
Posted by: Moderator to Vendor/Suppliers:Xilinx

Xilinx
Jeff Weintraub
San Jose, CA
www.xilinx.com


Xilinx leads one of the fastest growing segments of the semiconductor industry - programmable logic devices. Xilinx develops, manufactures, and markets a broad line of advanced integrated circuits, software design tools and intellectual property. As Xilinx devices are standard parts that are ready to be programmed, customers are not required to wait for prototypes or pay large up-front engineering costs, as with fixed logic or ASICs. Xilinx products are used in a wide array of digital electronic applications ranging from wireless base stations to DVD players. Unlike traditional semiconductor companies that have a few hundred customers, Xilinx has more than 7,500 customers worldwide and more than 50,000 design starts.

Igus Inc. develops and manufactures industry-leading, plastic-based cable carriers, continuous-flex cables and plain and linear bearings. With more than 28,000 products, the company markets its Energy Chain Systems® to guide and protect moving cables and hoses, Chainflex® cables designed specifically for use in Energy Chain Systems, iglide® self-lubricating, oil-free, plastic bearings, DryLin® linear guide systems and igubal® spherical bearings worldwide. Services include full in-house harnessing, design consultation, on-site consultation, guarantee and warranty. Igus works with its customers on an individual basis to deliver solutions that meet the specific needs of an application and all products are available from stock. We also donate product samples to students and engineers for use in various robotics competitions.

Maximizing Torque at Desired Speed
Within the constraints of power input and motor size, Lin Engineering can design a motor to maximize torque at your desired operating speed. With a given power input, the power output Td (T= torque at angular velocity )
from a given size of motor will not change. In other words, we design a motor’s maximum operating efficiency at your speed.
High Step Accuracy
High Resolution
Smooth Motion
Excellent Engineering Support
Extensive Sales Network
Short Lead Time
Military/ Aerospace Applications
As a military qualified vendor, Lin Engineering designed, tested, and manufactured disk drive step motors used in the B-2 Stealth bomber.

item.title: SpaceAge Control, Inc.
item.author: Moderator
item.description:
Posted by: Moderator to Vendor/Suppliers:SpaceAge Control, Inc.

SpaceAge Control, Inc.
Sales Department
Palmdale, CA
www.spaceagecontrol.com/


Produce all-environment miniature displacement transducers also referred to as draw wire transducers, string pots, string encoders, cable extension transducers, and yo yo pots. Complementary to LVDTs, encoders, linear potentiometers, and related displacement sensors, SpaceAge Control position transducers are noted for their small size, rugged performance, accuracy, flexible mounting, and easy installation.

Also produce air data products that obtain aircraft angle of attack (AOA, alpha), sideslip (AOS, beta), static pressure, total pressure (pitot static), outside air temperature (OAT), and total air temperature (TAT). Typical names for these devices are nose booms, wing booms, nosebooms, air data probes, pitot probes, pitot static probes, trailing cones, and trailing bombs. These products provide pressure and airflow direction data to data acquisition and air data computers for computation of aircraft orientation, airspeed, altitude, and related information.

National Instruments

For more than 25 years, National Instruments has revolutionized the way scientists and engineers work by leveraging the personal computer and its related technologies. Around the world, National Instruments is changing the way measurements are made by providing the software, hardware, and technologies necessary to transform personal computers into powerful computer-based and networked measurement and automation systems. Whether testing cars at Honda in Japan, validating cardiac defibrillators at Teletronics in Australia, or increasing test efficiency of phone lines at British Telecom in the UK, companies using NI products can achieve their goals - faster, better, and well under budget.

item.title: Systronix
item.author: Moderator
item.description:
Posted by: Moderator to Vendor/Suppliers:Systronix

Systronix
Bruce Boyes
Salt Lake City, UT
www.jrealtime.com


Systronix is perhaps the world leader in high speed, native-execution Java, realtime control systems. These systems are "lean and mean" and offer the benefits of Java programming in a power-efficient, compact, simple, and robust architecture. The Java 'virtual machine' and 'operating system' are embedded in silicon, rather than in firmware. This means that our JStik and JStamp systems are much simpler, faster, smaller, and more reliable than a typical embedded PC with megabytes of operating system and firmware JVMs. Our systems are currently in use in industry, robotics, and university research labs world-wide.

Inertial Solutions (IS) interfaces your navigation computer to a GPS receiver, an Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU), 4 high speed counter inputs, 2 spare analog inputs, and a flux gate compass - through an IO processor (32 bit MC68332). One of the serial channels (UART) connects to your navigation computer

The IMU constantly and independently tracks and maintains vertical reference and heading. Processor output directly controls 8 servo channels. Radio Control Manual Override is helpful during development testing.

IS will provide the flux gate compass at no cost to DARPA Challenger buyers of the system, and reduce processor card price from $695 to $300.

Total is $1,785 for IMU, GPS, Compass, Servo Control (with Manual Override), and Processor.

We will work with you to specify your requirements to help your project succeed. The extra technical support that we provide is no cost to you.

item.title: Commercial Products
item.author: Moderator
item.description:
Posted by: Moderator to Vendor/Suppliers:Commercial Products

Commercial Products
Bruce Boyes
Salt Lake City, UT
www.jrealtime.com


Systronix is perhaps the world leader in high speed, native-execution Java, realtime control systems. These systems are "lean and mean" and offer the benefits of Java programming in a power-efficient, compact, simple, and robust architecture. The Java 'virtual machine' and 'operating system' are embedded in silicon, rather than in firmware. This means that our JStik and JStamp systems are much simpler, faster, smaller, and more reliable than a typical embedded PC with megabytes of operating system and firmware JVMs. Our systems are currently in use in industry, robotics, and university research labs world-wide.

item.title: National Instruments
item.author: Moderator
item.description:
Posted by: Moderator to Vendor/Suppliers:National Instruments

National Instruments
Michael Zeller
Austin, TX
www.ni.com


For more than 25 years, National Instruments has revolutionized the way scientists and engineers work by leveraging the personal computer and its related technologies. Around the world, National Instruments is changing the way measurements are made by providing the software, hardware, and technologies necessary to transform personal computers into powerful computer-based and networked measurement and automation systems. Whether testing cars at Honda in Japan, validating cardiac defibrillators at Teletronics in Australia, or increasing test efficiency of phone lines at British Telecom in the UK, companies using NI products can achieve their goals - faster, better, and well under budget.
